**Novak Djokovic** ([Serbian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbian_language "Serbian language"): Новак Ђоковић, _Novak Đoković_, .mw-parser-output .IPA-label-small{font-size:85%}.mw-parser-output .references .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .infobox .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .navbox .IPA-label-small{font-size:100%}pronounced [\[nôʋaːk dʑôːkoʋitɕ\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/Serbo-Croatian "Help:IPA/Serbo-Croatian") <sup class="ext-phonos-attribution noexcerpt navigation-not-searchable"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Sr_Novak_Djokovic.ogg" title="File:Sr Novak Djokovic.ogg">ⓘ</a></sup>;<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-8">[6]</a></sup> born 22 May 1987) is a Serbian professional [tennis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis "Tennis") player who is currently ranked [world No. 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ATP_number_1_ranked_singles_tennis_players#Weeks_at_No._1 "List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players") in singles by the [Association of Tennis Professionals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_of_Tennis_Professionals "Association of Tennis Professionals") (ATP). Djokovic has been ranked No. 1 for a record total of 426 weeks in a record 13 different years, and finished as the [year-end No. 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ATP_number_1_ranked_singles_tennis_players#Year-end_No._1_players "List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players") a record eight times.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-9">[7]</a></sup> Djokovic has won a record 24 [Grand Slam men's singles titles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Grand_Slam_men%27s_singles_champions "List of Grand Slam men's singles champions"), including a record ten [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Open "Australian Open") titles. Overall, he has won 98 singles titles, including a record 71 [Big Titles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ATP_Tour_top-level_tournament_singles_champions#Statistics "List of ATP Tour top-level tournament singles champions"): 24 majors, a record 40 [Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_Masters_Series_records_and_statistics#Title_leaders "Tennis Masters Series records and statistics"), and a record seven [ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Finals "ATP Finals"). Djokovic is the only man in tennis history to be the reigning champion of all four majors at once across three different surfaces. In singles, he is the only man to achieve a [triple Career Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Grand_Slam_men%27s_singles_champions#Career_Grand_Slam "List of Grand Slam men's singles champions"), and the only player to complete a [career Golden Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_Masters_Series_records_and_statistics#Career_Golden_Masters "Tennis Masters Series records and statistics"), a feat he has achieved twice.

Djokovic began his professional career in 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-10">[8]</a></sup> In 2008, at age 20, he disrupted [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer") and [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal")'s streak of 11 consecutive majors by winning his first major title at the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2008 Australian Open – Men's singles"). By 2010, Djokovic had begun to separate himself from the rest of the field and, as a result, the trio of Federer, Nadal and Djokovic was referred to as the "[Big Three](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Three_(tennis) "Big Three (tennis)")" among fans and commentators. In [2011](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2011 Novak Djokovic tennis season"), Djokovic ascended to No. 1 for the first time, winning three majors and a then-record five Masters titles while going 10–1 against Nadal and Federer. He remained the most successful player in men's tennis for the rest of the decade.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-11">[9]</a></sup> In [2015](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2015 Novak Djokovic tennis season"), Djokovic had his most successful season, reaching a single-season record 15 consecutive finals, winning a season-record 10 Big Titles while having a record 31 victories over the top-10 players.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-12">[10]</a></sup> His dominant run extended through to the [2016 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2016 French Open – Men's singles"), where he completed his first [Career Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)#Career_Grand_Slam "Grand Slam (tennis)") and a [non-calendar year Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non_calendar_year_Grand_Slam "Non calendar year Grand Slam"), becoming the first man since [Rod Laver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rod_Laver "Rod Laver") in 1969 to hold all four majors simultaneously<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-13">[11]</a></sup> and setting a rankings points record of 16,950. In 2017, Djokovic suffered from an elbow injury that weakened his results until the [2018 Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles"), where he won the title while ranked No. 21 in the world. Djokovic has continued to be a dominant force on the tour since then, winning 12 major titles and completing his second and third Career Grand Slams. Due to his [opposition to COVID-19 vaccine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#Opposition_to_COVID-19_vaccine), Djokovic was forced to skip many tournaments in 2022,<sup id="cite_ref-willing_14-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-willing-14">[12]</a></sup> notably the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 Australian Open – Men's singles") and the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 US Open – Men's singles"); two major events he was the favourite to win.<sup id="cite_ref-22oddsAU_15-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-22oddsAU-15">[13]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22oddsUS_16-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-22oddsUS-16">[14]</a></sup> One year after the [Australian visa controversy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#Australian_Open_controversy), Djokovic made a successful comeback to reclaim the [2023 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2023 Australian Open – Men's singles") trophy,<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-17">[15]</a></sup> and shortly after he claimed the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2023 French Open – Men's singles") to take the outright record for most men's singles majors won in history.<sup id="cite_ref-23majors_18-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-23majors-18">[16]</a></sup>

Representing Serbia, Djokovic led the [national tennis team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia_Davis_Cup_team "Serbia Davis Cup team") to its first [Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Davis_Cup "2010 Davis Cup") title in 2010, and to the [inaugural ATP Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_ATP_Cup "2020 ATP Cup") title in 2020. He also won the [bronze medal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bronze_medal "Bronze medal") for his country at the [2008 Beijing Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics "Tennis at the 2008 Summer Olympics"). Djokovic is a recipient of the [Order of Karađorđe's Star](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_of_Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e%27s_Star "Order of Karađorđe's Star"), [Order of St. Sava](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_of_St._Sava "Order of St. Sava"), and the [Order of the Republika Srpska](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_of_the_Republika_Srpska "Order of the Republika Srpska"). His other awards include being named the [Laureus World Sportsman of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laureus_World_Sports_Award_for_Sportsman_of_the_Year "Laureus World Sports Award for Sportsman of the Year") a joint-record five times (2012, 2015, 2016, 2019, and 2024) and the 2011 [BBC Overseas Sports Personality of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_Overseas_Sports_Personality_of_the_Year "BBC Overseas Sports Personality of the Year").<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-19">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-20">[18]</a></sup>

Beyond competition, Djokovic was elected as the president of the ATP Player Council in 2016. He stepped down in 2020 to front a new player-only tennis association; the [Professional Tennis Players Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Professional_Tennis_Players_Association "Professional Tennis Players Association") (PTPA) founded by him and [Vasek Pospisil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vasek_Pospisil "Vasek Pospisil"), citing the need for players to have more influence on the tour and advocating better prize money structure for lower ranked players.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-21">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-22">[20]</a></sup> Djokovic is an active philanthropist. He is the founder of Novak Djokovic Foundation, which is committed to supporting children from disadvantaged communities.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-23">[21]</a></sup> Djokovic was appointed a [UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNICEF_Goodwill_Ambassador "UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador") in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-UNICEF_24-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-UNICEF-24">[22]</a></sup>

## Early and personal life

Novak Djokovic was born on 22 May 1987 in [Belgrade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade"), [SR Serbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Serbia "Socialist Republic of Serbia"), [SFR Yugoslavia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia"), to Dijana ([née](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birth_name#Maiden_and_married_names "Birth name") Žagar) and [Srdjan Djokovic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Srdjan_Djokovic "Srdjan Djokovic"). He is of paternal Serbian and maternal Croatian descent.<sup id="cite_ref-Chap1_25-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Chap1-25">[23]</a></sup> His two younger brothers, [Marko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marko_%C4%90okovi%C4%87 "Marko Đoković") and [Djordje](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Djordje_Djokovic "Djordje Djokovic"), have also played professional tennis.<sup id="cite_ref-biography_26-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-biography-26">[24]</a></sup>

Djokovic began playing tennis at the age of four,<sup id="cite_ref-biography_26-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-biography-26">[24]</a></sup> after his parents gave him a mini-racket and a soft foam ball, which his father said became "the most beloved toy in his life".<sup id="cite_ref-:0_27-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:0-27">[25]</a></sup> His parents then sent him to a tennis camp in [Novi Sad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novi_Sad "Novi Sad").<sup id="cite_ref-:0_27-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:0-27">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:1_28-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:1-28">[26]</a></sup> In the summer of 1993, as a six-year-old, he was sent to a tennis camp organized by the [Teniski Klub Partizan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teniski_Klub_Partizan "Teniski Klub Partizan") and overseen by Yugoslav tennis player [Jelena Genčić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jelena_Gen%C4%8Di%C4%87 "Jelena Genčić")<sup id="cite_ref-:1_28-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:1-28">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-29">[27]</a></sup> at [Mount Kopaonik](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kopaonik "Kopaonik"), where Djokovic's parents ran a fast-food parlour.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_27-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:0-27">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-spiegel_30-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-spiegel-30">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NYTimesintro_31-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-NYTimesintro-31">[29]</a></sup> Genčić worked with Djokovic over the following six years, convincing him to hit his backhand with two hands instead of the single hand used by his idol, [Pete Sampras](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pete_Sampras "Pete Sampras").<sup id="cite_ref-dare_2-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-dare-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-making1_32-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-making1-32">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nytimes_33-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-nytimes-33">[31]</a></sup> Djokovic has credited Genčić for "shaping my mind as a human being, but also as a professional".<sup id="cite_ref-ausopen_34-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-ausopen-34">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-reuters_35-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-reuters-35">[33]</a></sup>

During the [Yugoslav Wars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yugoslav_Wars "Yugoslav Wars") in the late 1990s, Serbia had to endure [embargoes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanctions_against_Yugoslavia "Sanctions against Yugoslavia")<sup id="cite_ref-reuters_35-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-reuters-35">[33]</a></sup> and [NATO bombings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NATO_bombing_of_Yugoslavia "NATO bombing of Yugoslavia")<sup id="cite_ref-biography_26-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-biography-26">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-spiegel_30-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-spiegel-30">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-making1_32-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-making1-32">[30]</a></sup> because of the [Kosovo War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kosovo_War "Kosovo War"). but that fear and exhaustion made him tougher and drove him to pursue tennis with greater determination.<sup id="cite_ref-biography_26-3" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-biography-26">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-36">[34]</a></sup> At one point he had to train inside a disused swimming pool converted into a tennis court.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-37">[35]</a></sup> Due to his rapid development, Genčić contacted [Nikola Pilić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikola_Pili%C4%87 "Nikola Pilić") and in September 1999 Djokovic moved to the Pilić tennis academy in [Oberschleißheim](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oberschlei%C3%9Fheim "Oberschleißheim"), Germany, spending four years there.<sup id="cite_ref-dare_2-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-dare-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-spiegel_30-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-spiegel-30">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-38">[36]</a></sup> Pilić made him serve against a wall for several months to improve his technique, and he had him working with a rubber exercise band for a year to improve flexibility in his wrist.<sup id="cite_ref-spiegel_30-3" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-spiegel-30">[28]</a></sup> One of the players he trained with at the Niki Pilić academy was future world No. 10 [Ernests Gulbis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernests_Gulbis "Ernests Gulbis"), with whom he allegedly had a fiery rivalry.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-39">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-40">[38]</a></sup>

His father also took him to train at academies in the United States, Italy and Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_27-3" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:0-27">[25]</a></sup> Because of the high cost of traveling and training his father took out high-interest loans to help pay for his son's tennis education, putting Djokovic under immense pressure to deliver.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_27-4" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:0-27">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-spiegel_30-4" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-spiegel-30">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-making1_32-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-making1-32">[30]</a></sup> He believes the impact this had on him could be the reason behind his prowess under pressure.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_28-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:1-28">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-spiegel_30-5" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-spiegel-30">[28]</a></sup>

He met his future wife, Jelena Ristić, in high school, and began dating her in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-41">[39]</a></sup> The two became engaged in September 2013,<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-42">[40]</a></sup> and on 10 July 2014 the couple were married on [Sveti Stefan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sveti_Stefan "Sveti Stefan") in Montenegro.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-43">[41]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-44">[42]</a></sup> He and Ristić had their first child, a boy, in October 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-45">[43]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-46">[44]</a></sup> Their daughter was born in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-47">[45]</a></sup>

Djokovic is a self-described fan of languages, speaking [Serbian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbian_language "Serbian language"), English, French, German, Italian, Portuguese, Chinese, Russian, Arabic, Japanese and Spanish.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-48">[46]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Pack_49-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Pack-49">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-50">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-51">[49]</a></sup>

### 2000s

#### 2001–2003: Juniors

Main article: [Novak Djokovic junior years](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic_junior_years "Novak Djokovic junior years")

In 2001, Djokovic dominated the U14 circuit in the ETA Junior Tour, currently known as the [Tennis Europe Junior Tour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_Europe_Junior_Tour "Tennis Europe Junior Tour"), winning his first ETA title in a second category tournament in [Messina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Messina "Messina"), defeating his compatriot [Bojan Božović](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bojan_Bo%C5%BEovi%C4%87_(tennis) "Bojan Božović (tennis)") in the final,<sup id="cite_ref-suu_52-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-suu-52">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-53">[51]</a></sup> and his second in [Livorno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Livorno "Livorno")<sup id="cite_ref-suu_52-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-suu-52">[50]</a></sup> after beating the top seed and [future rival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Djokovic%E2%80%93Murray_rivalry "Djokovic–Murray rivalry") [Andy Murray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray "Andy Murray") in the semifinals, and the second seed [Aljoscha Thron](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aljoscha_Thron "Aljoscha Thron") in the final, 5–7, 7–5, 6–4.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-54">[52]</a></sup> In July, Djokovic was the top seed at the [U14 European championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_European_Junior_Championships "Tennis European Junior Championships"), held in [Sanremo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanremo "Sanremo"), where he won the singles tournament over [Lukáš Lacko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luk%C3%A1%C5%A1_Lacko "Lukáš Lacko"),<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-55">[53]</a></sup> and the doubles with Božović over the Russian pair of [Alexandre Krasnoroutskiy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexandre_Krasnoroutskiy "Alexandre Krasnoroutskiy") and Mikhail Bekker.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-56">[54]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Raonic_57-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Raonic-57">[55]</a></sup> Djokovic also led the Serbian team to victory in the European Summer Cup,<sup id="cite_ref-suu_52-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-suu-52">[50]</a></sup> thus ending the year as a European champion in singles, doubles and in team competition, while also winning the silver medal at the [ITF World Junior Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITF_World_Junior_Championship "ITF World Junior Championship") for players under 14 in a team competition for Yugoslavia.<sup id="cite_ref-dare_2-3" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-dare-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-biography_26-4" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-biography-26">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-58">[56]</a></sup> Djokovic ended 2001 at the top of the ETA rankings for U14s, one place ahead of Murray at No. 2.<sup id="cite_ref-suu_52-3" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-suu-52">[50]</a></sup>

In 2002, Djokovic continued his dominance, now in the U16 circuit. In June, Djokovic won two prestigious tournaments in France, the Derby Cadets in _La Boule_, where he beat future world No. 6 [Gaël Monfils](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ga%C3%ABl_Monfils "Gaël Monfils") in the final,<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-59">[57]</a></sup> and _Le Pontet_ in [Avignon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avignon "Avignon").<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-60">[58]</a></sup> In September, Djokovic won his first ITF tournament in [Pančevo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pan%C4%8Devo "Pančevo")<sup id="cite_ref-dare_2-4" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-dare-2">[2]</a></sup> after winning all of his matches in straight sets, some of which against rivals three years older than him, including the No. 1 seed [David Savić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Savi%C4%87 "David Savić") in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-activity_61-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-activity-61">[59]</a></sup> In November, Djokovic participated in the prestigious Prince Cup and [Junior Orange Bowl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Junior_Orange_Bowl_(tennis) "Junior Orange Bowl (tennis)") in [Miami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami "Miami"), defeating home favourite Stephen Bass to win the former<sup id="cite_ref-activity_61-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-activity-61">[59]</a></sup> despite having to play the final just a few hours after winning a qualifier round for the Orange Bowl, where he beat two Americans in the main draw before losing in the third round to [Marcos Baghdatis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcos_Baghdatis "Marcos Baghdatis").<sup id="cite_ref-activity_61-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-activity-61">[59]</a></sup>

In juniors, he compiled a singles win-loss record of 40–11 (and 23–6 in doubles), reaching a combined junior world ranking of No. 24 in February 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-62">[60]</a></sup> At the junior Grand Slam events, his best showing was at the Australian Open where he reached [the semifinals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Boys%27_singles "2004 Australian Open – Boys' singles") in 2004. He also played at the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Boys%27_singles "2003 French Open – Boys' singles") and [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Boys%27_singles "2003 US Open – Boys' singles") junior events in 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-63">[61]</a></sup>

#### 2003–2005: Start of professional career

In January 2003, at age 15, Djokovic played his first match in a professional tournament after receiving a wildcard from Pilić to enter a [Futures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Futures_tournaments "Futures tournaments") event in Oberschleißheim, the suburb of Munich where Pilić had his academy, but despite knowing the court where he played very well, Djokovic still lost to [Alex Rădulescu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_R%C4%83dulescu "Alex Rădulescu") in two tight sets, 7–5, 7–6.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBowers2014chapter_five_64-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBowers2014chapter_five-64">[62]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-timeline_65-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-timeline-65">[63]</a></sup> Pilić also had influence outside of Germany and requested a wildcard for Djokovic to play in a Futures in Belgrade in June, where he beat the No. 4 seed in the first round and then Cesar Ferrer-Victoria in the final, gaining him his first world ranking of No. 767.<sup id="cite_ref-making2_66-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-making2-66">[64]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ranking_67-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Ranking-67">[65]</a></sup> At age 16, he finished 2003 ranked world No. 687.<sup id="cite_ref-making2_66-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-making2-66">[64]</a></sup>

On 11 April 2004, the 16-year-old Djokovic earned his first official ATP victory when he defeated No. 1340 [Janis Skroderis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janis_Skroderis "Janis Skroderis") 6–2, 6–2 in a dead rubber held in Belgrade during a Davis Cup tie between Serbia & Montenegro and Latvia.<sup id="cite_ref-bang_68-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-bang-68">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-69">[67]</a></sup> He won his first [ATP Challenger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Challenger_Series "ATP Challenger Series") tournament in [Budapest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Budapest_Challenger_(May) "Budapest Challenger (May)"), where he started as a qualifier.<sup id="cite_ref-biography_26-5" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-biography-26">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Shorthistory_70-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Shorthistory-70">[68]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bang_68-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-bang-68">[66]</a></sup> In the final, played on the day of his 17th birthday, Djokovic dominated No. 232 [Daniele Bracciali](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniele_Bracciali "Daniele Bracciali") 6–1, 6–2.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-71">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-72">[70]</a></sup> Djokovic then qualified for his first ATP Tour event, the Croatia Open Umag in July 2004, where he lost to [Filippo Volandri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filippo_Volandri "Filippo Volandri") in the first round.<sup id="cite_ref-bang_68-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-bang-68">[66]</a></sup> His success in Futures and Challenger events saw him rise into the world's Top 200 and finish 2004 as the world No. 186.<sup id="cite_ref-making2_66-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-making2-66">[64]</a></sup>

In January 2005, Djokovic made his Grand Slam debut at the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2005 Australian Open – Men's singles"), where he defeated future rival [Stan Wawrinka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka "Stan Wawrinka") in the second round of the [qualifying competition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_qualifying#Fifteenth_Qualifier "2005 Australian Open – Men's singles qualifying").<sup id="cite_ref-Stanimal_73-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Stanimal-73">[71]</a></sup> In the first round of the main draw, he was defeated by eventual champion [Marat Safin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marat_Safin "Marat Safin") in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-making2_66-3" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-making2-66">[64]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bang_68-3" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-bang-68">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-74">[72]</a></sup> Later that year, Djokovic won his first Grand Slam match at the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2005 French Open – Men's singles"), and went on to reach the third round of both [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2005 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles") and the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2005 US Open – Men's singles"), coming back from two sets down and saving multiple match points to defeat [Guillermo García López](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guillermo_Garc%C3%ADa_L%C3%B3pez "Guillermo García López") in the former, and beating [Gaël Monfils](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ga%C3%ABl_Monfils "Gaël Monfils") and [Mario Ančić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mario_An%C4%8Di%C4%87 "Mario Ančić") in the latter. Djokovic participated in four Masters events and qualified for two of them, his best performance coming in [Paris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_BNP_Paribas_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2005 BNP Paribas Masters – Singles"), where he reached the third round and defeated fourth seed [Mariano Puerta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mariano_Puerta "Mariano Puerta") along the way.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-75">[73]</a></sup> He finished the year ranked No. 78, the youngest player in the top 100.<sup id="cite_ref-bang_68-4" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-bang-68">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Pack_49-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Pack-49">[47]</a></sup>

#### 2006: Maiden ATP titles, first Grand Slam quarterfinal

On 9 April 2006, Djokovic clinched a decisive Davis Cup win against Great Britain by defeating [Greg Rusedski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Rusedski "Greg Rusedski") in four sets in the fourth match of the tie, giving [Serbia and Montenegro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia_and_Montenegro "Serbia and Montenegro") an insurmountable 3–1 lead in their best-of-five series, thus keeping the country in the [Group One Euro/African Zone of Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davis_Cup_structure "Davis Cup structure"). Afterwards, Djokovic briefly considered moving from Serbia to play for Great Britain.<sup id="cite_ref-Hodgkinson_76-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Hodgkinson-76">[74]</a></sup> The British media spoke of Djokovic's family negotiating with the [Lawn Tennis Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawn_Tennis_Association "Lawn Tennis Association") about changing his international loyalty by joining British tennis ranks.<sup id="cite_ref-Hodgkinson_76-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Hodgkinson-76">[74]</a></sup> The 18-year-old Djokovic, who was ranked 64th in the world, initially dismissed the story by saying that the talks were not serious, describing them as "the British being very kind to us after the Davis Cup."<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-77">[75]</a></sup> However, more than three years later, in October 2009, Djokovic confirmed that the talks between his family and the LTA throughout April and May 2006 were indeed serious:

.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 32px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}

> Britain was offering me a lot of opportunities and they needed someone because Andy \[Murray\] was the only one, and still is. That had to be a disappointment for all the money they invest. But I didn't need the money as much as I had done. I had begun to make some for myself, enough to afford to travel with a coach, and I said, "Why the heck?" I am Serbian, I am proud of being a Serbian, I didn't want to spoil that just because another country had better conditions. If I had played for Great Britain, of course I would have played exactly as I do for my country but deep inside, I would never have felt that I belonged. I was the one who took the decision.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-78">[76]</a></sup>

Djokovic reached his first Grand Slam quarterfinal at the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2006 French Open – Men's singles") as the world No. 63, after upsetting ninth-ranked [Fernando González](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fernando_Gonz%C3%A1lez "Fernando González") in the second round.<sup id="cite_ref-1April_79-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-1April-79">[77]</a></sup> In the quarterfinals, he faced [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal"), the first-ever meeting of their [historic rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Djokovic%E2%80%93Nadal_rivalry "Djokovic–Nadal rivalry"), which Nadal won via a retirement from Djokovic after Nadal took the first two sets.<sup id="cite_ref-1April_79-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-1April-79">[77]</a></sup> This deep run at the French Open saw him reach the top 40 in the world singles rankings. At [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2006 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles"), he reached the fourth round, losing to seventh seed [Mario Ančić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mario_An%C4%8Di%C4%87 "Mario Ančić") in five sets.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-80">[78]</a></sup>

Three weeks after Wimbledon, Djokovic won his maiden ATP title at the [Dutch Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_Open_(tennis) "Dutch Open (tennis)") in [Amersfoort](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amersfoort "Amersfoort") without losing a set, defeating [Nicolás Massú](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Mass%C3%BA "Nicolás Massú") in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-1April_79-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-1April-79">[77]</a></sup> He won his second career title at the [Moselle Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moselle_Open "Moselle Open") in [Metz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metz "Metz"), France, defeating [Jürgen Melzer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Melzer "Jürgen Melzer") in the final, and moved into the top 20.<sup id="cite_ref-1April_79-3" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-1April-79">[77]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-81">[79]</a></sup> He also reached his first career Masters quarterfinal at [Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006_Mutua_Madrile%C3%B1a_Masters_Madrid_%E2%80%93_Singles "2006 Mutua Madrileña Masters Madrid – Singles") during the indoor hardcourt season.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-82">[80]</a></sup> Djokovic finished the year ranked No. 16, the youngest player in the top 20.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-83">[81]</a></sup>

#### 2007: First Masters titles, first Major final & breaking top 3

Djokovic began 2007 by defeating Australian [Chris Guccione](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Guccione_(tennis) "Chris Guccione (tennis)") in the [Adelaide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Next_Generation_Adelaide_International_%E2%80%93_Singles "2007 Next Generation Adelaide International – Singles") final, before losing in the fourth round of the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Australian_Open "2007 Australian Open") to eventual champion Roger Federer<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-84">[82]</a></sup> in straight sets. His performances at the [Masters Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Masters_Series "ATP Masters Series") events in [Indian Wells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Wells_Open "Indian Wells Open"), and [Miami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony_Ericsson_Open "Sony Ericsson Open"), where he was the runner-up and champion respectively, pushed him into the world's top 10.<sup id="cite_ref-1April_79-4" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-1April-79">[77]</a></sup> Djokovic lost the Indian Wells final to Rafael Nadal, but defeated Nadal in Key Biscayne in the quarterfinals before going on to defeat [Guillermo Cañas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guillermo_Ca%C3%B1as "Guillermo Cañas") in the final to win his maiden Masters Series title.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-85">[83]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cruises_86-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-cruises-86">[84]</a></sup> In doing so, he became the youngest player to ever win the tournament and the first teenager to win the event since [Andre Agassi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andre_Agassi "Andre Agassi") in 1990.<sup id="cite_ref-1April_79-5" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-1April-79">[77]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cruises_86-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-cruises-86">[84]</a></sup>

Djokovic then returned to Serbia to help his country enter the [Davis Cup World Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Davis_Cup_World_Group_play-offs "2007 Davis Cup World Group play-offs")<sup id="cite_ref-Georgia_87-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Georgia-87">[85]</a></sup> in a match against [Georgia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgia_Davis_Cup_team "Georgia Davis Cup team"). He won a point by defeating Georgia's [George Chanturia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Chanturia "George Chanturia").<sup id="cite_ref-Georgia_87-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Georgia-87">[85]</a></sup> Later, he played in the [Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_Open "Monte Carlo Open"), where he was defeated by [David Ferrer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Ferrer "David Ferrer") in the third round, and at the [Estoril Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portugal_Open "Portugal Open"), where he defeated [Richard Gasquet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Gasquet "Richard Gasquet") in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-88">[86]</a></sup> Djokovic then reached the quarterfinals of both the [Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internazionali_d%27Italia "Internazionali d'Italia") in Rome, where he lost to Nadal, and the [Hamburg Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamburg_Masters "Hamburg Masters"), where he was defeated by Carlos Moyá. At the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2007 French Open – Men's singles"), Djokovic reached his first major semifinal, losing to eventual champion Nadal.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-89">[87]</a></sup>

At [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Wimbledon_Championships "2007 Wimbledon Championships"), Djokovic won a five-hour quarterfinal against [Marcos Baghdatis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcos_Baghdatis "Marcos Baghdatis") to reach his first Wimbledon semi-final.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-90">[88]</a></sup> At the time, the match had lasted just 5 minutes shy of the longest Wimbledon match played in a single day. After the match, Baghdatis stated that playing against Djokovic was “a bit like facing Andre Agassi. He is just making you move from one place to another”.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-91">[89]</a></sup> Djokovic started his semifinal match against Nadal with nearly 17 hours on court, and ended up retiring with elbow problems in the third set, after winning the first and losing the second set.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-92">[90]</a></sup>

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Novak_Djokovic_2007_US_Open.jpg/220px-Novak_Djokovic_2007_US_Open.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Novak_Djokovic_2007_US_Open.jpg)

Djokovic during his first round match at the [2007 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_US_Open_(tennis) "2007 US Open (tennis)")

Djokovic's next tournament was the [Canadian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Canada_Masters "2007 Canada Masters") in Montreal, and he defeated No. 3 [Andy Roddick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Roddick "Andy Roddick") in the quarterfinals, No. 2 Nadal in the semifinals, and No. 1 Federer in the final. This was the first time a player had defeated the top three ranked players in one tournament since [Boris Becker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boris_Becker "Boris Becker") in 1994.<sup id="cite_ref-timeline_65-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-timeline-65">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-93">[91]</a></sup> Djokovic was also only the second player, after [Tomáš Berdych](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom%C3%A1%C5%A1_Berdych "Tomáš Berdych"), to have defeated both Federer and Nadal since they became the top two players in the world. After this tournament, [Björn Borg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bj%C3%B6rn_Borg "Björn Borg") stated that Djokovic "is definitely a contender to win a Grand Slam (tournament)."<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-94">[92]</a></sup> The following week at the [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Masters "Cincinnati Masters"), Djokovic lost in the second round to Moyà in straight sets. Nevertheless, he went on to reach the final of the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_US_Open_(tennis) "2007 US Open (tennis)"), where he had five set points in the first set and two in the second set, but lost them all before losing the match in straight sets to the top-seeded Federer.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-95">[93]</a></sup>

Djokovic won his fifth title of the year at the [BA-CA TennisTrophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BA-CA_TennisTrophy "BA-CA TennisTrophy") in Vienna, defeating [Stanislas Wawrinka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanislas_Wawrinka "Stanislas Wawrinka") in the final. His next tournament was the [Madrid Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madrid_Open_(tennis) "Madrid Open (tennis)"), where he lost to [David Nalbandian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Nalbandian "David Nalbandian") in the semifinals. Djokovic, assured of finishing the year ranked No. 3, qualified for the [year-ending championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Tennis_Masters_Cup "2007 Tennis Masters Cup"), but did not advance beyond the [round robin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Round-robin_tournament "Round-robin tournament") matches. He received the [Golden Badge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Badge "Golden Badge") award for the best athlete in Serbia, and the [Olympic Committee of Serbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Committee_of_Serbia "Olympic Committee of Serbia") declared him the best athlete in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-96">[94]</a></sup>

Djokovic played a key role in the [2007 play-off](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Davis_Cup_World_Group_play-offs#Serbia_vs._Australia "2007 Davis Cup World Group play-offs") win over [Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_Davis_Cup_team "Australia Davis Cup team") by winning all his matches and helping promote the [Serbia Davis Cup team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia_Davis_Cup_team "Serbia Davis Cup team") to the [2008 World Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Davis_Cup_World_Group "2008 Davis Cup World Group").<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-97">[95]</a></sup> In Serbia's tie against [Russia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia_Davis_Cup_Team "Russia Davis Cup Team") in Moscow in early 2008, Djokovic was sidelined due to [influenza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Influenza "Influenza") and missed his first singles match. He returned to win his doubles match, teaming with [Nenad Zimonjić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nenad_Zimonji%C4%87 "Nenad Zimonjić"), before retiring during his singles match with [Nikolay Davydenko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikolay_Davydenko "Nikolay Davydenko").<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-98">[96]</a></sup>

#### 2008: First Major title, two Masters & first Year-end Championship

Main article: [2008 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2008 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

Djokovic started his preparations for the season by playing the [Hopman Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hopman_Cup "Hopman Cup") with fellow Serbian world No. 3 [Jelena Janković](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jelena_Jankovi%C4%87 "Jelena Janković") where he won all of his four singles matches, including in the final against the United States, where he beat Mardy Fish in a deciding set tiebreak to level the tie, but then losing the decisive mixed doubles rubber,<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-99">[97]</a></sup> in which he faced former [WTA No. 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_WTA_number_1_ranked_singles_tennis_players "List of WTA number 1 ranked singles tennis players") [Serena Williams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serena_Williams "Serena Williams") in a competitive event for the first time.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-100">[98]</a></sup> At the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Australian_Open "2008 Australian Open"), Djokovic reached his second consecutive Grand Slam final, this time without dropping a set, including a victory over two-time defending champion Federer in the semifinals.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-101">[99]</a></sup> By reaching the semifinals, Djokovic became the youngest player in the Open Era to have reached the semifinals in all four Grand Slam events.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-102">[100]</a></sup> In the final, Djokovic defeated unseeded Frenchman [Jo-Wilfried Tsonga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jo-Wilfried_Tsonga "Jo-Wilfried Tsonga") in four sets to earn his first Grand Slam singles title.<sup id="cite_ref-dte_103-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-dte-103">[101]</a></sup> This marked the first time since the 2005 Australian Open that a Grand Slam singles title was not won by Federer or Nadal.<sup id="cite_ref-dte_103-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-dte-103">[101]</a></sup>

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Nole_Skupstina_BG_feb08.jpg/220px-Nole_Skupstina_BG_feb08.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Nole_Skupstina_BG_feb08.jpg)

Djokovic celebrating his first [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2008 Australian Open – Men's singles") triumph in [Belgrade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade")

Djokovic's next tournament was the [Dubai Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dubai_Tennis_Championships "Dubai Tennis Championships"), where he lost in the semifinals to Roddick. At the [Indian Wells Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Pacific_Life_Open "2008 Pacific Life Open"), Djokovic won his ninth career singles title, defeating Mardy Fish in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-104">[102]</a></sup> Djokovic won his tenth career singles title and fourth Master Series singles crown at the [Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Italian_Open_(tennis) "2008 Italian Open (tennis)") in Rome after defeating Wawrinka in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-105">[103]</a></sup> The following week he lost to Nadal in the semifinals at the [Hamburg Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Hamburg_Masters "2008 Hamburg Masters"). At the French Open, Djokovic was the third-seeded player behind Federer and Nadal. He lost to Nadal in the semifinals in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-106">[104]</a></sup>

On [grass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grass_court "Grass court"), Djokovic once again played Nadal, this time in the [Artois Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Stella_Artois_Championships_%E2%80%93_Singles "2008 Stella Artois Championships – Singles") final in [Queen's Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen%27s_Club "Queen's Club"), where he lost in two sets. Djokovic entered Wimbledon seeded third but lost in the second round to [Marat Safin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marat_Safin "Marat Safin"), ending a streak of five consecutive majors where he had reached at least the semifinals.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-107">[105]</a></sup>

Djokovic then failed to defend his 2007 singles title at the [Rogers Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Rogers_Cup "2008 Rogers Cup") in [Toronto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toronto "Toronto"), where he was eliminated in the quarterfinals by [Andy Murray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray "Andy Murray"). The following week at the [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Western_%26_Southern_Financial_Group_Masters "2008 Western & Southern Financial Group Masters"), Djokovic advanced to the final, beating Nadal in the semifinals, which not only ended the Spaniard's 32-match winning streak, but also delayed Nadal's first ascension to world No. 1 by a week.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-108">[106]</a></sup> In the final, he again lost to Murray in straight sets. His next tournament was the [2008 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer Olympics"), his first Olympics. He and Nenad Zimonjić, seeded second in men's doubles, were eliminated in the first round by the Czech pairing of [Martin Damm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Damm "Martin Damm") and [Pavel Vízner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pavel_V%C3%ADzner "Pavel Vízner"). Seeded third in singles, Djokovic lost in the semifinals to Nadal. Djokovic then defeated [James Blake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Blake_(tennis) "James Blake (tennis)"), the loser of the other semifinal, in the bronze medal match.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-109">[107]</a></sup>

After the Olympics, Djokovic entered the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2008 US Open – Men's singles") seeded third, where he defeated Roddick in the quarterfinals. To a smattering of boos in a post-match interview, Djokovic criticized Roddick for accusing him of making excessive use of the trainer during matches and for suggesting that he was faking his injuries.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-110">[108]</a></sup> His run at the US Open ended in the semifinals when he lost to Federer in four sets, in a rematch of the previous year's final. In November, Djokovic was the second seed at the year-ending [Tennis Masters Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Tennis_Masters_Cup_%E2%80%93_Singles "2008 Tennis Masters Cup – Singles") in Shanghai, beating [Juan Martín del Potro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Mart%C3%ADn_del_Potro "Juan Martín del Potro") and [Nikolay Davydenko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikolay_Davydenko "Nikolay Davydenko") in the round-robin stage, and [Gilles Simon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilles_Simon "Gilles Simon") in the semifinals. In the final, Djokovic defeated Davydenko to win his first title at the year-end championship.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-111">[109]</a></sup>

#### 2009: Ten finals, five titles

Main article: [2009 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2009 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

Djokovic started the year at the [Brisbane International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brisbane_International "Brisbane International"), where he was upset by fellow Pilić academy trainee [Ernests Gulbis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernests_Gulbis "Ernests Gulbis") in the first round.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-112">[110]</a></sup> As defending champion at the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Australian_Open "2009 Australian Open"), Djokovic retired from his quarterfinal match with former world No. 1 Andy Roddick, primarily due to heat illness that generated muscle aches and cramps.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-113">[111]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-114">[112]</a></sup> After losing in the semifinals of the [Open 13](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_13 "Open 13") tournament in Marseille to Tsonga, Djokovic won the singles title at the [Dubai Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Dubai_Tennis_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2009 Dubai Tennis Championships – Men's singles"), defeating Ferrer to claim his twelfth career title.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-115">[113]</a></sup> The following week, Djokovic was the defending champion at the [Indian Wells Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Wells_Masters "Indian Wells Masters") but lost to Roddick in the quarterfinals. At the [Miami Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Miami_Masters "2009 Miami Masters") in Key Biscayne, Djokovic beat Federer in the semifinals, before losing to Murray in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-116">[114]</a></sup>

Djokovic reached the final of the next Masters event, the [Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters "2009 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters") on clay, losing to Nadal in the final. At the [Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Italian_Open_(tennis) "2009 Italian Open (tennis)") in Rome, Djokovic failed to defend the title he had won the previous year, losing to Nadal in the final again.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-117">[115]</a></sup> Djokovic was the top seed at his hometown tournament, the [Serbia Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia_Open "Serbia Open") in Belgrade, beating [Łukasz Kubot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C5%81ukasz_Kubot "Łukasz Kubot") in the final to win his second title of the year.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-118">[116]</a></sup> Djokovic then reached the semifinals of the [Madrid Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Mutua_Madrile%C3%B1a_Madrid_Open "2009 Mutua Madrileña Madrid Open") without dropping a set, where he lost to Nadal despite holding three match points. The match, at 4 hours and 3 minutes, was at the time the longest three-set singles match on the ATP Tour in the Open Era.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-119">[117]</a></sup> At the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_French_Open "2009 French Open"), he lost in the third round to German [Philipp Kohlschreiber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philipp_Kohlschreiber "Philipp Kohlschreiber").

Djokovic began his grass court season at the [Gerry Weber Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Gerry_Weber_Open "2009 Gerry Weber Open") where after the withdrawal of Federer, he competed as the top seed. He advanced to the final, where he lost to [Tommy Haas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tommy_Haas "Tommy Haas").<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-120">[118]</a></sup> Djokovic then lost to Haas again, this time in the quarterfinals of [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2009 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles").<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-121">[119]</a></sup> During the [US Open Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_US_Open_Series "2009 US Open Series"), Djokovic made the quarterfinals of the [Canadian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Rogers_Cup "2009 Rogers Cup") in Montreal before losing to Roddick. At the [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Western_%26_Southern_Financial_Group_Masters "2009 Western & Southern Financial Group Masters"), Djokovic defeated Nadal in the semifinals before losing in the final to Federer.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-122">[120]</a></sup> At the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2009 US Open – Men's singles"), Djokovic reached the semifinals, where he was defeated by Federer.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-123">[121]</a></sup>

Djokovic then won his third title of the year at the [China Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_China_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2009 China Open – Men's singles") in Beijing, beating [Marin Čilić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marin_%C4%8Cili%C4%87 "Marin Čilić") in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-124">[122]</a></sup> Djokovic then lost in the semifinals of the inaugural [Shanghai Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Shanghai_ATP_Masters_1000 "2009 Shanghai ATP Masters 1000") to Davydenko. At the [Swiss Indoors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Davidoff_Swiss_Indoors "2009 Davidoff Swiss Indoors") in [Basel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basel "Basel"), Djokovic recorded his first 6–0, 6–0 win at an elite event when he defeated [Jan Hernych](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jan_Hernych "Jan Hernych") in the second round.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-125">[123]</a></sup> He then defeat home player Wawrinka in the quarterfinals before saving three match to win his semifinal against [Radek Štěpánek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radek_%C5%A0t%C4%9Bp%C3%A1nek "Radek Štěpánek"). In the final, he defeated home favourite and three-time defending champion Federer to win his fourth title of the year.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-126">[124]</a></sup> Djokovic won his first Masters title of the year at the [Paris Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_BNP_Paribas_Masters "2009 BNP Paribas Masters") after defeating Nadal in the semifinals, and outlasting [Gaël Monfils](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ga%C3%ABl_Monfils "Gaël Monfils") in a decisive set tiebreak in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-127">[125]</a></sup>

Even though he came into the year-ending [ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_ATP_World_Tour_Finals "2009 ATP World Tour Finals") in London on a 10-match winning streak and as the defending champion, Djokovic failed to make it out from the round-robin stage despite beating both Davydenko and Nadal due to having fewer sets.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-128">[126]</a></sup> Djokovic ended the year as the No. 3 for the third consecutive year, having played 97 matches, the most of any player on the ATP Tour, which earned him the Ironman nickname, with a 78–19 win–loss record. In addition to leading the ATP Tour in match wins, he reached a career-best ten finals, winning five titles.<sup id="cite_ref-Ironman_129-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Ironman-129">[127]</a></sup>

### 2010s

#### 2010: US Open final & Davis Cup crown

Main article: [2010 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2010 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

After playing nearly a hundred matches in 2009, Djokovic stated that he was "fed up with matches", so he decided not to play any ranking tournaments before the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2010 Australian Open – Men's singles"), thus starting his year by playing in the [AAMI Classic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AAMI_Classic "AAMI Classic"), an exhibition event, where he beat Tommy Haas, but lost to [Fernando Verdasco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fernando_Verdasco "Fernando Verdasco") and teenager [Bernard Tomic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_Tomic "Bernard Tomic").<sup id="cite_ref-Ironman_129-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Ironman-129">[127]</a></sup> At the Australian Open, Djokovic lost a five-setter to Tsonga in the quarterfinals.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-130">[128]</a></sup> Despite the loss, he attained a career-high ranking of No. 2 and went on to reach the semifinals in [Rotterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_ABN_AMRO_World_Tennis_Tournament "2010 ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament"), where he lost to [Mikhail Youzhny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mikhail_Youzhny "Mikhail Youzhny"). At the [Dubai Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Dubai_Tennis_Championships "2010 Dubai Tennis Championships"), Djokovic reached the final, this time defeating Youzhny to win his first title of the year and to successfully defend a title for the first time in his career.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-131">[129]</a></sup>

On 6–8 March 2010, Djokovic then took part in Serbia's [Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Davis_Cup "2010 Davis Cup") tie against the [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Davis_Cup_team "United States Davis Cup team") on clay in Belgrade, where he played a key role in helping his country reach the quarterfinal in the Davis Cup for the first time in its independent history, winning both singles matches against [Sam Querrey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Querrey "Sam Querrey") and [John Isner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Isner "John Isner") in a 3–2 victory.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-132">[130]</a></sup> After early exits at the [Indian Wells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_BNP_Paribas_Open "2010 BNP Paribas Open") and [Miami Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Sony_Ericsson_Open "2010 Sony Ericsson Open"), Djokovic announced that he had ceased working with [Todd Martin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Todd_Martin "Todd Martin") as his coach.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-133">[131]</a></sup>

In his first clay-court tournament of the year at the [Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters "2010 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters"), top-seeded Djokovic reached the semifinals with wins over Wawrinka and [David Nalbandian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Nalbandian "David Nalbandian") before losing to Verdasco. Djokovic again lost to Verdasco at the [Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Italian_Open_(tennis) "2010 Italian Open (tennis)") in Rome, this time in the quarterfinals.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-134">[132]</a></sup> As the defending champion at his hometown event, the [Serbia Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Serbia_Open "2010 Serbia Open") in Belgrade, he withdrew in the quarterfinals while trailing No. 319 [Filip Krajinović](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filip_Krajinovi%C4%87 "Filip Krajinović"),<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-135">[133]</a></sup> the lowest-ranked player to ever beat Djokovic as well as the only time that Djokovic lost to a player outside the Top 200.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-136">[134]</a></sup> Djokovic entered the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2010 French Open – Men's singles") seeded third, where he lost to [Jürgen Melzer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Melzer "Jürgen Melzer") in five sets, marking the only time he lost a match at a major after leading two sets to love.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-137">[135]</a></sup> Djokovic then won the first ATP doubles titles of his career at the [Aegon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Aegon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Doubles "2010 Aegon Championships – Doubles"), pairing with [Jonathan Erlich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Erlich "Jonathan Erlich") to beat [Karol Beck](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karol_Beck "Karol Beck") and [David Škoch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_%C5%A0koch "David Škoch") in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-138">[136]</a></sup> In [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2010 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles"), he lost in the semifinals to [Tomáš Berdych](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom%C3%A1%C5%A1_Berdych "Tomáš Berdych") in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-139">[137]</a></sup>

Djokovic then competed at the [Canadian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Rogers_Cup "2010 Rogers Cup") in Toronto, where he lost to Federer in the semifinals. Djokovic also competed in doubles with Nadal in a one-time, high-profile partnership. This had not happened since 1976, when [Jimmy Connors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Connors "Jimmy Connors") and [Arthur Ashe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Ashe "Arthur Ashe") as No. 1 and No. 2 paired together as a doubles team.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-140">[138]</a></sup> They lost in the first round to Canadians [Milos Raonic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milos_Raonic "Milos Raonic") and [Vasek Pospisil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vasek_Pospisil "Vasek Pospisil"). Djokovic then lost to Roddick in the quarterfinals of the [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Western_%26_Southern_Financial_Group_Masters "2010 Western & Southern Financial Group Masters").<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-141">[139]</a></sup> As the third seed at the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2010 US Open – Men's singles"), Djokovic came very close to losing in his opening round against Viktor Troicki in extreme heat. He then defeated [Philipp Petzschner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philipp_Petzschner "Philipp Petzschner"), James Blake, Mardy Fish, and Gaël Monfils, all in straight sets, to reach the US Open semifinals for the fourth consecutive year. There, he defeated Federer in five sets after saving two match points with forehand winners while serving to stay in the match at 4–5 in the fifth set. It was Djokovic's first victory over Federer at the US Open in four attempts, and his first victory over Federer in a Major since the 2008 Australian Open. Djokovic went on to lose to Nadal in the final, a match that saw Nadal complete his career Grand Slam.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-142">[140]</a></sup>

After helping Serbia defeat the Czech Republic 3–2 to make it to the Davis Cup final, Djokovic competed at the [China Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_China_Open_(tennis) "2010 China Open (tennis)") as the top seed and defending champion. He won the title for the second successive year after defeating [David Ferrer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Ferrer "David Ferrer") in the final. At the Shanghai Masters, Djokovic made a semifinal appearance, losing to Federer. Djokovic played his final tournament of the year at the [ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Finals "ATP World Tour Finals") in London, where he lost to Federer in the semifinals.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-143">[141]</a></sup>

Serbia progressed to the Davis Cup final, following the victories over [Croatia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Croatia_Davis_Cup_team "Croatia Davis Cup team") (4–1) and the [Czech Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Czech_Republic_Davis_Cup_team "Czech Republic Davis Cup team") (3–2). Serbia came from 1–2 down to defeat [France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France_Davis_Cup_team "France Davis Cup team") in the final tie 3–2 in Belgrade to win the nation's first Davis Cup Championship. In the final, Djokovic scored two singles points for Serbia, defeating Gilles Simon and Gaël Monfils.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-144">[142]</a></sup> He was the backbone of the Serbian squad, going 7–0 in singles rubbers to lead the nation to the title, although the honour of winning the deciding rubber in the final went to compatriot Viktor Troicki. This two singles rubbers wins started a long unbeaten run that went on into 2011. Djokovic finished the year ranked No. 3, his fourth successive finish at this position. He was awarded the title "Serbian Sportsman of the year" by the [Olympic Committee of Serbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Committee_of_Serbia "Olympic Committee of Serbia") and "Serbian Athlete of the year" by [DSL Sport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DSL_Sport "DSL Sport").<sup id="cite_ref-Shorthistory_70-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Shorthistory-70">[68]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-145">[143]</a></sup>

#### 2011: Rise to the top in one of the greatest seasons in history

Main article: [2011 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2011 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

[![Novak Djokovic celebrates his 2011 Wimbledon semi-final win over Jo-Wilfried Tsonga. The victory meant that Djokovic successfully clinched the ATP world No. 1 Ranking for the first time in his career on 1 July 2011. He also reached his first-ever Wimbledon final, which he eventually won.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Novak_Djokovic_Wimbledon_2011_semifinal_win_celebration_-_croped_and_edited.jpg/300px-Novak_Djokovic_Wimbledon_2011_semifinal_win_celebration_-_croped_and_edited.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Novak_Djokovic_Wimbledon_2011_semifinal_win_celebration_-_croped_and_edited.jpg)

Djokovic celebrates upon defeating [Jo-Wilfried Tsonga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jo-Wilfried_Tsonga "Jo-Wilfried Tsonga") in the semifinals of the [2011 Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2011 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles"), clinching the [world No. 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ATP_number_1_ranked_singles_tennis_players "List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players") ranking for the first time in his career.

Djokovic began his season by winning the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2011 Australian Open – Men's singles"). He only dropped one set en route to the title, beating Federer in the semifinals and Murray in the final to capture his second Australian Open title and his first grand slam in three years.<sup id="cite_ref-AOFINAL_146-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-AOFINAL-146">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AUSSFONE_147-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-AUSSFONE-147">[145]</a></sup>

He next competed at the [Dubai Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Dubai_Tennis_Championships "2011 Dubai Tennis Championships") and beat Federer in the final in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-148">[146]</a></sup> Two weeks later, Djokovic won his second [Indian Wells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_BNP_Paribas_Open "2011 BNP Paribas Open") title after beating Federer in the semifinals and Nadal in the final, both in three sets, thus becoming only the
