third player to beat Nadal and Federer in the same tournament twice, joining Nikolay Davydenko and David Nalbandian.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-149">[147]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-IWFL_150-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-IWFL-150">[148]</a></sup> In [Miami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Sony_Ericsson_Open "2011 Sony Ericsson Open"), Djokovic once again beat Nadal in the finals in three sets, with the final set being decided in a tiebreak.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-151">[149]</a></sup> After winning the [Serbia Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Serbia_Open "2011 Serbia Open"), Djokovic won the [Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Mutua_Madrile%C3%B1a_Madrid_Open "2011 Mutua Madrileña Madrid Open") and [Italian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Italian_Open_(tennis) "2011 Italian Open (tennis)") Opens, beating Nadal in straight sets in both finals.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-152">[150]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-reversal_153-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-reversal-153">[151]</a></sup> Beating Nadal in back-to-back matches on clay was a notable reversal due to the fact that he had previously lost all nine matches played against Nadal on clay.<sup id="cite_ref-reversal_153-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-reversal-153">[151]</a></sup>

He continued his good form on clay at the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_French_Open "2011 French Open") by dropping only one set en route to the semifinal, which he lost to Federer. This loss marked Djokovic's first defeat of the season (with Federer also being the last man to defeat Djokovic in 2010), ending a 43-match win streak, which included a 41–0 start to 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-154">[152]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-155">[153]</a></sup> Five weeks later at [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Wimbledon_Championships "2011 Wimbledon Championships"), Djokovic replaced Nadal as the world No. 1 and then defeated him in a four set final to take his first Wimbledon title.<sup id="cite_ref-YEN1_156-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-YEN1-156">[154]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-157">[155]</a></sup>

In [Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Rogers_Cup "2011 Rogers Cup"), Djokovic won his single-season record-breaking fifth Masters title with a three-set win over Mardy Fish in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-158">[156]</a></sup> At the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_US_Open_(tennis) "2011 US Open (tennis)"), Djokovic beat Federer and Nadal on the way to the title, thus becoming only the second player to defeat both of them in the same Major event after [Juan Martín del Potro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Mart%C3%ADn_del_Potro "Juan Martín del Potro") in the 2009 US Open.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-159">[157]</a></sup> Djokovic [saved match points en route to the title](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Grand_Slam_related_tennis_records#Won_a_title_after_saving_match_points "List of Grand Slam related tennis records"), saving two against Federer in the semifinals to complete a comeback from two sets down,<sup id="cite_ref-save_160-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-save-160">[158]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Mitchell_161-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Mitchell-161">[159]</a></sup> thus becoming just the second player to beat Federer from two sets down after Tsonga a few months earlier in Wimbledon.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-162">[160]</a></sup> Djokovic's crosscourt forehand return winner to save the first match point is widely regarded as one of the greatest shots in US Open history as well as one of the greatest returns in tennis history.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-163">[161]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-164">[162]</a></sup> This was the second consecutive US Open where Djokovic saved two match points against Federer to reach the final, and the fifth consecutive US Open where Djokovic and Federer played each other.<sup id="cite_ref-save_160-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-save-160">[158]</a></sup> Djokovic played Nadal in their second successive major final, winning the match in four sets and taking his first US Open title.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-165">[163]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-US11_166-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-US11-166">[164]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-167">[165]</a></sup>

With the victory, Djokovic extended his season record to an impressive 64–2.<sup id="cite_ref-US11_166-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-US11-166">[164]</a></sup> However, his level dropped toward the season's end, beginning with a back injury sustained during the US Open which caused him to retire from the [Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Davis_Cup "2011 Davis Cup"), and ending with a poor showing at the [ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_ATP_World_Tour_Finals "2011 ATP World Tour Finals"), in which he lost to [David Ferrer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Ferrer "David Ferrer") and [Janko Tipsarević](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janko_Tipsarevi%C4%87 "Janko Tipsarević"), but saved match point against [Tomáš Berdych](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom%C3%A1%C5%A1_Berdych "Tomáš Berdych") to seal his 70th and final win of the year.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-168">[166]</a></sup> Djokovic concluded the season with a 70–6 record and a year-end ranking of No. 1. He was named the 2011 [ITF World Champion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITF_World_Champions "ITF World Champions").<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-169">[167]</a></sup>

In total, Djokovic won ten tournaments in 2011,<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimesintro_31-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-NYTimesintro-31">[29]</a></sup> including three Grand Slam tournament victories at the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2011 Australian Open – Men's singles"), [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2011 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles"), and the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2011 US Open – Men's singles").<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimesintro_31-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-NYTimesintro-31">[29]</a></sup> He also captured a then-record-breaking five [ATP Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Masters_1000 "ATP World Tour Masters 1000") titles,<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimesintro_31-3" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-NYTimesintro-31">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-170">[168]</a></sup> and won $12.6 million on the ATP Tour.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimesintro_31-4" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-NYTimesintro-31">[29]</a></sup> Djokovic lost only two matches from the start of the season until the final match of the US Open in September, going 10–1 against Nadal and Federer, the other two best players of the year, including 6–0 against Nadal, all in Big Title finals.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-171">[169]</a></sup> Djokovic also had the most dominant record versus a world No. 1 for a single season, going 5–0 against Nadal before overtaking him as the world No. 1.

[Pete Sampras](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pete_Sampras "Pete Sampras") declared Djokovic's 2011 season as the best he had seen in his lifetime, calling it "one of the best achievements in all of the sports."<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-172">[170]</a></sup> [Boris Becker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boris_Becker "Boris Becker") called Djokovic's season "one of the very best years in tennis of all time", noting that it "may not be the best statistically, but he's beaten Federer, he's beaten Nadal, he's beaten everybody that came around to challenge him in the biggest tournaments in the world."<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-173">[171]</a></sup> Rafael Nadal, who lost to Djokovic in six finals on hard, clay and grass courts, described Djokovic's performances as "probably the highest level of tennis that I ever saw."<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-174">[172]</a></sup>

#### 2012: Australian Open title, three Masters & Year-end Championship

Main article: [2012 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2012 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

Djokovic began his season by winning the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2012 Australian Open – Men's singles"). In the quarterfinals, he defeated [David Ferrer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Ferrer "David Ferrer") in three sets. In the semifinal, Djokovic beat Andy Murray in five sets after 4 hours and 50 minutes, recovering from a two-sets-to-one deficit and fending off break points at 5-all in the fifth set, in a rematch of [the previous year's final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2011 Australian Open – Men's singles").<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-175">[173]</a></sup> In [the final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final "2012 Australian Open – Men's singles final"), Djokovic beat Rafael Nadal in five sets, recovering from losing the first set and then a break down in the final set to win 7–5. At 5 hours and 53 minutes, the match was the longest Grand Slam final in Open Era history, as well as the longest match in Australian Open history, surpassing the 5-hour and 14-minute 2009 semifinal between Nadal and Fernando Verdasco.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-176">[174]</a></sup>

Djokovic was beaten by [John Isner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Isner "John Isner") in the semifinals at [Indian Wells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_BNP_Paribas_Open "2012 BNP Paribas Open"). He successfully defended his title in [Miami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Sony_Ericsson_Open "2012 Sony Ericsson Open") after beating Murray in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-177">[175]</a></sup> In the [Monte Carlo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters "2012 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters") final, he lost in straight sets to Nadal. Djokovic also lost in straight sets to Nadal at the [2012 Rome Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Rome_Masters "2012 Rome Masters") final.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-178">[176]</a></sup>

Djokovic reached his maiden [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2012 French Open – Men's singles") final by defeating Roger Federer,<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-179">[177]</a></sup> reaching the final of all four majors consecutively. Djokovic had the chance to become the first man since [Rod Laver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rod_Laver "Rod Laver") in 1969 to hold all four major titles at once, having won last year's [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2011 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles") and [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2011 US Open – Men's singles") titles as well as [this year's Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final "2012 Australian Open – Men's singles final"), but was beaten by Nadal in the final in four sets.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-180">[178]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-181">[179]</a></sup> Following the French Open, Djokovic failed to defend his title in [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2012 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles"), losing to Roger Federer in four sets in the semifinals.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-182">[180]</a></sup>

At the [2012 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics "2012 Summer Olympics") in London, Djokovic was chosen as the flag bearer for Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-183">[181]</a></sup> On 2 August 2012, Djokovic defeated French fifth seed [Jo-Wilfried Tsonga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jo-Wilfried_Tsonga "Jo-Wilfried Tsonga") and advanced to the semifinals, where he was beaten by Murray in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-184">[182]</a></sup> In the bronze medal match he lost to [Juan Martín del Potro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Mart%C3%ADn_del_Potro "Juan Martín del Potro"), finishing fourth.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-185">[183]</a></sup> He successively defended his Rogers Cup title, dropping just a single set to [Tommy Haas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tommy_Haas "Tommy Haas"). Following the Rogers Cup, Djokovic made the final of the [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Masters "Cincinnati Masters") but lost to Federer in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-186">[184]</a></sup>

At the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2012 US Open – Men's singles"), Djokovic reached his third consecutive final by beating fourth-seeded David Ferrer in a match suspended a day due to rain.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-187">[185]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-188">[186]</a></sup> He then lost to Murray in a [five set final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final "2012 US Open – Men's singles final") that lasted 4 hours and 54 minutes, the joint-longest US Open in history.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-189">[187]</a></sup> This final also set the records for both the longest tiebreak (24 minutes) and the longest rally (54 shots) in a major final, won by Murray and Djokovic respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-190">[188]</a></sup> Djokovic went on to defend his [China Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_China_Open_(tennis) "2012 China Open (tennis)") title, defeating Tsonga in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-191">[189]</a></sup> The following week he won the Shanghai Masters by defeating Murray in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-192">[190]</a></sup> With Federer's withdrawal from the Paris Masters, Djokovic regained the No. 1 ranking.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-193">[191]</a></sup> On 12 November 2012, Djokovic won the [2012 ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_ATP_World_Tour_Finals "2012 ATP World Tour Finals") by defeating Federer in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-194">[192]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-195">[193]</a></sup> Because of his achievements in the 2012 season, Djokovic was named the 2012 [ITF World Champion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITF_World_Champions "ITF World Champions") in men's singles by the [International Tennis Federation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Tennis_Federation "International Tennis Federation").<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-196">[194]</a></sup>

#### 2013: Australian Open title, three Masters & Year-end Championship

Main article: [2013 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2013 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

Djokovic started his preparations for the 2013 season by playing the [Hopman Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Hopman_Cup "2013 Hopman Cup") with [Ana Ivanovic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ana_Ivanovic "Ana Ivanovic"), winning three of his four singles matches, including in the final against [Fernando Verdasco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fernando_Verdasco "Fernando Verdasco") of Spain in an eventual 1–2 loss.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-197">[195]</a></sup> In his first competitive tournament of the year, Djokovic beat Stan Wawrinka in a five-set epic in the fourth round of the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2013 Australian Open – Men's singles"), lasting over five hours, and being deemed to be one of the best matches ever played,<sup id="cite_ref-:12_198-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:12-198">[196]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:10_199-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:10-199">[197]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:11_200-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:11-200">[198]</a></sup> with Wawrinka deeming it to have been the best match that he ever played.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-201">[199]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:13_202-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:13-202">[200]</a></sup> He later defeated Andy Murray in the final of the to win a record third consecutive Australian Open trophy and the sixth major of his career.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-203">[201]</a></sup> A week later, he participated in a [Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Davis_Cup_World_Group "2013 Davis Cup World Group") match against [Belgium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belgium_Davis_Cup_team "Belgium Davis Cup team"), where he defeated [Olivier Rochus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olivier_Rochus "Olivier Rochus") to give the Serbian team a 2–0 lead.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-204">[202]</a></sup>

On 2 March 2013, Djokovic defeated [Tomáš Berdych](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom%C3%A1%C5%A1_Berdych "Tomáš Berdych") in the final of the [Dubai Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Dubai_Tennis_Championships "2013 Dubai Tennis Championships").<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-205">[203]</a></sup> Another solid week of tennis saw Djokovic reach the semifinals at the [Indian Wells Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_BNP_Paribas_Open "2013 BNP Paribas Open"), before losing to [Juan Martín del Potro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Mart%C3%ADn_del_Potro "Juan Martín del Potro"), ending his 22-match winning streak.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-206">[204]</a></sup> The following week, Djokovic entered the [Miami Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Sony_Open_Tennis "2013 Sony Open Tennis") as the defending champion, but lost in the fourth round to [Tommy Haas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tommy_Haas "Tommy Haas") in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-207">[205]</a></sup>

In April, Djokovic played for Serbia against the [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Davis_Cup_Team "United States Davis Cup Team") in the Davis Cup quarterfinals. Djokovic clinched a tie for his team by defeating [John Isner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Isner "John Isner") and [Sam Querrey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Querrey "Sam Querrey").<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-208">[206]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-209">[207]</a></sup> Later that month, he defeated eight-time champion [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal") in straight sets in the final of the [Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters "2013 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters") to clinch his first title in Monte Carlo.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-210">[208]</a></sup> In May, he was defeated by [Grigor Dimitrov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grigor_Dimitrov "Grigor Dimitrov") in three sets in the second round of the [Madrid Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Mutua_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2013 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's singles") in Madrid.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-211">[209]</a></sup> The following week, he lost to Berdych at the quarterfinal stage of the Rome Masters.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-212">[210]</a></sup>

Djokovic began his [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2013 French Open – Men's singles") campaign with wins over [David Goffin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Goffin "David Goffin"), [Guido Pella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guido_Pella "Guido Pella"), and Dimitrov in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-213">[211]</a></sup> In the fourth round he recovered from a set down and defeated [Philipp Kohlschreiber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philipp_Kohlschreiber "Philipp Kohlschreiber") of Germany in four sets.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-214">[212]</a></sup> In the process, he reached a 16th consecutive Grand Slam quarterfinal, which he won over [Tommy Haas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tommy_Haas "Tommy Haas"). Djokovic then lost to Nadal in the semifinal in a five-set epic.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-215">[213]</a></sup>

At [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2013 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles"), Djokovic defeated [Juan Martín del Potro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Mart%C3%ADn_del_Potro "Juan Martín del Potro") in a five-set epic that lasted 4 hours and 44 minutes, which at the time was the longest Wimbledon semifinal in history.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-216">[214]</a></sup> Djokovic then lost the final to Murray in straight sets. At the [Canadian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Rogers_Cup "2013 Rogers Cup"), he lost to Nadal in the semifinal in three sets. Later, Djokovic lost to Isner in the quarterfinals in Cincinnati. Djokovic went on to reach the [US Open final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2013 US Open – Men's singles"), where he met Nadal for the 37th time in his career (a new Open Era record). He went on to lose in four sets.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-217">[215]</a></sup> In early October, Djokovic collected his fourth Beijing title by defeating Nadal in the final in straight sets. He also collected his second Shanghai Masters title, extending his winning streak to 20–0 over the last two seasons at the hard-court Asian swing of the tour.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-218">[216]</a></sup> Djokovic won his 16th Masters title in Paris at the end of the season, beating David Ferrer in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-219">[217]</a></sup> At the [2013 ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_ATP_World_Tour_Finals "2013 ATP World Tour Finals") Djokovic retained his trophy, beating Nadal in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-220">[218]</a></sup> At the end of the season, [Boris Becker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boris_Becker "Boris Becker") joined his staff as head coach.

#### 2014: Wimbledon title, four Masters & Year-end Championship

Main article: [2014 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2014 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

Djokovic began the year with a warmup tournament win, the [2013 Mubadala Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Mubadala_World_Tennis_Championship_%E2%80%93_Singles "2013 Mubadala World Tennis Championship – Singles"). At the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2014 Australian Open – Men's singles"), he won his first four matches in straight sets against [Lukáš Lacko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luk%C3%A1%C5%A1_Lacko "Lukáš Lacko"), [Leonardo Mayer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leonardo_Mayer "Leonardo Mayer"), [Denis Istomin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Istomin "Denis Istomin"), and No. 15 seed [Fabio Fognini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fabio_Fognini "Fabio Fognini") respectively. He met Wawrinka in the quarterfinals of the tournament, the second consecutive year the two had met at the event. Despite coming back from two sets to one down, Djokovic fell 9–7 in the fifth set, ending his 25–match winning streak in Melbourne, as well as his streak of 14 consecutive Grand Slam tournament semifinals.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-221">[219]</a></sup>

Djokovic won his third [Indian Wells Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Wells_Masters "Indian Wells Masters") title, defeating Federer in the final. Continuing his good run, he beat No. 1 Nadal in the final of the [Miami Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Sony_Open_Tennis_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2014 Sony Open Tennis – Men's singles") in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-222">[220]</a></sup> Suffering from a wrist injury which hampered him throughout the [Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters "2014 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters"), Djokovic lost the semifinals to Federer in straight sets. After returning from injury, Djokovic won his third Rome title by beating Nadal in the final of the [Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Italian_Open_(tennis) "2014 Italian Open (tennis)").<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-223">[221]</a></sup> He subsequently donated the $500,000 in prize money that he had received to the victims of the [2014 Southeast Europe floods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Southeast_Europe_floods "2014 Southeast Europe floods").<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-224">[222]</a></sup>

Djokovic reached the final of the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_French_Open "2014 French Open") losing only two sets in six matches but lost in the final to Nadal in four sets.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-225">[223]</a></sup> It was Djokovic's first defeat in the last 5 matches between both. At the [Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Wimbledon_Championships "2014 Wimbledon Championships") Djokovic defeated [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer") in the [final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final "2014 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles final") in five sets, winning with a scoreline of 6–7, 6–4, 7–6, 5–7, 6–4. With this victory he replaced Rafael Nadal again as the world No. 1.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-226">[224]</a></sup> Djokovic played at the [Canadian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Rogers_Cup "2014 Rogers Cup"), losing to eventual first-time champion [Jo-Wilfried Tsonga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jo-Wilfried_Tsonga "Jo-Wilfried Tsonga") in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-227">[225]</a></sup> He followed that with a loss to Tommy Robredo at the Cincinnati Masters. At the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_US_Open_(tennis) "2014 US Open (tennis)"), Djokovic reached the semifinals, where he lost in four sets to [Kei Nishikori](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kei_Nishikori "Kei Nishikori").<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-228">[226]</a></sup>

Djokovic returned to Beijing with a fifth trophy in six years, defeating Murray in the semifinal and Berdych in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-229">[227]</a></sup> The following week he was beaten by Federer in the semifinal of [Shanghai Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2014 Shanghai Rolex Masters – Singles"). He then won the [Paris Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_BNP_Paribas_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2014 BNP Paribas Masters – Singles") title, without losing a single set, beating Raonic in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-230">[228]</a></sup>

In the ATP Finals, Djokovic created a record by winning three round-robin matches with a loss of just nine games. By reaching the semifinal, he also secured the year-end No. 1 ranking for the third time, tying him with Nadal in the fifth position. He was awarded the [ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_ATP_World_Tour_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles "2014 ATP World Tour Finals – Singles") trophy after Federer withdrew before the final.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-231">[229]</a></sup> This marked the seventh title of the season for him and the fourth title at the year-end event.

#### 2015: One of the greatest tennis seasons of all time

Main article: [2015 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2015 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

Djokovic began the season at the [Qatar Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Qatar_ExxonMobil_Open "2015 Qatar ExxonMobil Open") in Doha, where he won his first two rounds for the loss of just 6 games, however, lost in the quarterfinals against [Ivo Karlović](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivo_Karlovi%C4%87 "Ivo Karlović") in three tight sets. He rebounded from this defeat well at the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2015 Australian Open – Men's singles"), where he made it through the first five rounds without dropping a set. In the semifinals, he faced defending champion [Stan Wawrinka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka "Stan Wawrinka"), the man who beat him the previous year. He twice lost a set lead, however, came roaring back in the fifth to take it to love, and set up a third final against [Andy Murray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray "Andy Murray"). After splitting the first two sets in [tiebreakers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiebreaker "Tiebreaker"), Djokovic found his form after dropping his serve at the start of the third set, going on to win 12 of the last 13 games to record a four-set victory over the Scot, and win an Open Era record-breaking fifth title in Melbourne, overtaking [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer") and [Andre Agassi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andre_Agassi "Andre Agassi").<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-232">[230]</a></sup> He moved into equal eighth on the all-time list of men with the most Major titles, tying Agassi, [Ivan Lendl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivan_Lendl "Ivan Lendl"), [Jimmy Connors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Connors "Jimmy Connors"), [Ken Rosewall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ken_Rosewall "Ken Rosewall") and [Fred Perry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fred_Perry "Fred Perry").<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-233">[231]</a></sup>

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Novak_Djokovic%2C_Qatar_Open_2016.jpg/300px-Novak_Djokovic%2C_Qatar_Open_2016.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Novak_Djokovic,_Qatar_Open_2016.jpg)

Djokovic sliding on a hard court to get a ball back

He next competed at the [Dubai Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Dubai_Tennis_Championships "2015 Dubai Tennis Championships") and lost to Federer in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-234">[232]</a></sup> After 2 weeks, Djokovic defeated [John Isner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Isner "John Isner") and Andy Murray en route to his 21st [Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Tour_Masters_1000 "ATP Tour Masters 1000") title, beating Federer in three sets in [Indian Wells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2015 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles").<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-235">[233]</a></sup> In [Miami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Miami_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2015 Miami Open – Men's singles"), he defeated David Ferrer and John Isner en route to winning his fifth title defeating Andy Murray in three sets. With his 22nd Masters title, Djokovic became the first player to complete the [Indian Wells – Miami title double](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Open_(tennis)#Sunshine_Double "Miami Open (tennis)") three times.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-236">[234]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-237">[235]</a></sup> In April, Djokovic clinched his second [Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2015 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters – Singles") by beating Tomáš Berdych in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-238">[236]</a></sup> Therefore, Djokovic became the first man to win the first three [ATP Masters 1000](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Masters_1000_tournaments "ATP Masters 1000 tournaments") titles of the season.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-239">[237]</a></sup> Djokovic withdrew from the 2015 Madrid Masters.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-240">[238]</a></sup> He won the title for the fourth time at the [Rome Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2015 Italian Open – Men's singles"), making it 4 out of 4 titles in Masters events entered by Djokovic in the season.

He continued his good form on clay at the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2015 French Open – Men's singles") by reaching the final without dropping a set in the first five rounds, including a quarterfinal clash with [Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal") and a five-set semifinal victory over No. 3 seed Andy Murray which took two days to complete. This meant he became only the second man to have won against Nadal at the French Open. However, he lost the next match and the tournament to No. 8 seed [Stan Wawrinka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka "Stan Wawrinka") in four sets.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-241">[239]</a></sup> Five weeks later, he rebounded again from the tough loss in Paris, just like 2014, coming from two sets down to beat [Kevin Anderson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Anderson_(tennis) "Kevin Anderson (tennis)") in the fourth round, and then going on to claim his third [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2015 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles") title, with a four-set win over Roger Federer.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-242">[240]</a></sup>

Prior to the final Grand Slam event of the year, Djokovic had the chance to become the first man in history to complete the full set of Masters titles in [Cincinnati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Western_%26_Southern_Open "2015 Western & Southern Open"), achieving the [Career Golden Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Tour_Masters_1000#Career_Golden_Masters "ATP Tour Masters 1000"), but he lost the final to Federer (Djokovic would accomplish the feat at the [2018](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Western_%26_Southern_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 Western & Southern Open – Men's singles") and [2020](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Western_%26_Southern_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2020 Western & Southern Open – Men's singles") events).<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-243">[241]</a></sup> At the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2015 US Open – Men's singles"), Djokovic reached the final for the sixth time in his career, achieving the feat of reaching all four Grand Slam finals in a single calendar year. In the final, he faced Federer once again, defeating him in four sets to win his third Grand Slam title of the year, his second title at Flushing Meadows, and his tenth Grand Slam singles title overall, becoming the fifth man in the Open Era to win double-digit Grand Slam singles titles, as well as only the third man to reach all four Major finals in a calendar year.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-244">[242]</a></sup>

He returned to [China Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_China_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2015 China Open – Men's singles") in October, winning the title for the sixth time, defeating Nadal in straight sets in the final to bring his overall record at the tournament to 29–0.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-245">[243]</a></sup> Djokovic then reached the final of the [Paris Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_BNP_Paribas_Masters "2015 BNP Paribas Masters"), where he defeated Murray in straight sets, taking his fourth title there and a record sixth ATP Masters tournament in one year.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-246">[244]</a></sup> After losing to Federer in the round-robin stage of the [ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_ATP_World_Tour_Finals "2015 ATP World Tour Finals") he took on the third seed again in the final. He beat Federer in straight sets winning his fifth ATP Finals title and becoming the first player to win the Year-end Championships four consecutive times.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-247">[245]</a></sup>

By the end of the season, Djokovic made a season-record 15 consecutive finals, reaching the championship match of every top-level tournament he played (four in Majors, eight in Masters, and the final at the Year-end Championships). He won 11 titles including a season-record 10 [Big Titles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ATP_Tour_top-level_tournament_singles_champions#Statistics "List of ATP Tour top-level tournament singles champions") (three Majors, six Masters, and the Year-end Championships) on all court surfaces and conditions (hard, clay, grass and indoors). Djokovic set a season-record of 16,585 for most ranking points accumulated as world No. 1. and had a season-record 31 victories over top-10 players, including a remarkable 15–4 winning record against the other members of the Big Four, Federer, Nadal, and Murray. The 2015 season is Djokovic's most successful season as of 2022, and it is considered one of the greatest seasons in tennis history.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-248">[246]</a></sup>

#### 2016: Historic 'Nole Slam', four Masters & ranking points record

Main article: [2016 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2016 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Djokovic_2016.jpg/200px-Djokovic_2016.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Djokovic_2016.jpg)

Djokovic kissing [Coupe des Mousquetaires](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coupe_des_Mousquetaires "Coupe des Mousquetaires") after winning the [2016 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_French_Open "2016 French Open"), completing "Nole Slam" and his first career Grand Slam

Djokovic collected his 60th career title in [Doha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Qatar_ExxonMobil_Open "2016 Qatar ExxonMobil Open"), defeating [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal") in two sets in a final that lasted 73 minutes. He broke his own ATP ranking points record, bringing it up to 16,790. Djokovic then proceeded to win his sixth [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2016 Australian Open – Men's singles"). On his road to his [Open Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Era "Open Era") record sixth title in Melbourne, he defeated [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer") in four sets in the semifinals, and in a rematch of the 2015 final, he defeated [Andy Murray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray "Andy Murray"), in three straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-cnn.com.ao_249-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-cnn.com.ao-249">[247]</a></sup> He quickly rebounded from an eye infection at the [Dubai Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Dubai_Tennis_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2016 Dubai Tennis Championships – Men's singles") to collect a fifth [Indian Wells Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2016 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles") title, defeating Rafael Nadal in the semifinals, and [Milos Raonic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milos_Raonic "Milos Raonic") in the final. Djokovic's run was so dominant that the world no. 2 and 3 (Andy Murray and Roger Federer) could have combined their points and still not have had enough to pass him in the rankings.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-250">[248]</a></sup>

On 3 April 2016, Djokovic won the [Miami Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Miami_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2016 Miami Open – Men's singles") for the third consecutive year, and did so without dropping a set en route to his sixth career [Miami Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Open_(tennis) "Miami Open (tennis)") title, tying him with [Andre Agassi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andre_Agassi "Andre Agassi") for most ever Miami Open men's singles titles.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-251">[249]</a></sup> In addition, the victory marked the fourth year Djokovic completed the [Sunshine Double](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Open_(tennis)#Sunshine_Double "Miami Open (tennis)") in his career, the most Sunshine Doubles out of any player in history, and 2016 being the third consecutive year that Djokovic completed it. His win in Miami also saw Djokovic surpass Roger Federer to become the all-time leading prize money winner on the ATP tour with career earnings of $98.2 million.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-252">[250]</a></sup> After an early round exit at the [Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2016 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters – Singles"),<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-253">[251]</a></sup> Djokovic quickly bounced back by winning the [Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Mutua_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2016 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's singles") title for the second time in his career, with a three-set victory over Murray.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-254">[252]</a></sup> They met again in the [Rome Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2016 Italian Open – Men's singles") final one week later with Murray as the victor; despite a sluggish performance, Djokovic defeated Nadal and [Kei Nishikori](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kei_Nishikori "Kei Nishikori") in two long quarterfinals and semifinals.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-255">[253]</a></sup>

Djokovic defeated Andy Murray in the final of the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2016 French Open – Men's singles") in four sets, making him the reigning champion of all four major tournaments, a historic feat the media dubbed the [Nole Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)#Non-calendar-year_Grand_Slam "Grand Slam (tennis)").<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-256">[254]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-257">[255]</a></sup> With his French Open triumph, Djokovic became the eighth player in history to achieve a [Career Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)#Career_Grand_Slam "Grand Slam (tennis)"), the third player in history after [Don Budge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don_Budge "Don Budge") and [Rod Laver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rod_Laver "Rod Laver") to hold all four Grand Slam titles at the same time, and the first player to win $100 million in prize money.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-258">[256]</a></sup> The victory at the French Open brought his ATP ranking points up to a new record of 16,950.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-259">[257]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-260">[258]</a></sup> At [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2016 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles"), his major win streak came to an end in the third-round when he lost to American [Sam Querrey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Querrey "Sam Querrey") in four sets. It was his earliest exit in a Grand Slam since the [2009 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2009 French Open – Men's singles").<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-261">[259]</a></sup>

In late July, Djokovic returned to form by winning his fourth [Canadian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Rogers_Cup_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2016 Rogers Cup – Men's singles") title, and 30th Masters title overall, without dropping a set.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-262">[260]</a></sup> In August, Djokovic was beaten in the first round of the [Olympic men's singles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's singles") in Rio de Janeiro by [Juan Martín del Potro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Mart%C3%ADn_del_Potro "Juan Martín del Potro"). It was Djokovic's first opening round defeat since January 2009, when [Ernest Gulbis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernest_Gulbis "Ernest Gulbis") defeated him at the [2009 Brisbane International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Brisbane_International_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2009 Brisbane International – Men's singles").<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-263">[261]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-264">[262]</a></sup> In the final slam of the year, the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2016 US Open – Men's singles"), Djokovic advanced to the final but was defeated by [Stan Wawrinka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka "Stan Wawrinka") in four sets.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-265">[263]</a></sup> Djokovic was defeated by [Roberto Bautista Agut](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Bautista_Agut "Roberto Bautista Agut") and [Marin Čilić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marin_%C4%8Cili%C4%87 "Marin Čilić") in the semifinals and quarterfinals of [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2016 Shanghai Rolex Masters – Singles") and [Paris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_BNP_Paribas_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2016 BNP Paribas Masters – Singles"). Due to this result, he lost the No. 1 ranking to [Andy Murray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray "Andy Murray").<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-266">[264]</a></sup> However, a runner-up finish at the [ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_ATP_World_Tour_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles "2016 ATP World Tour Finals – Singles") indicated his best performances in nearly three months. After the season, he parted ways with his coach of three years, [Boris Becker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boris_Becker "Boris Becker").<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-267">[265]</a></sup>

#### 2017: Split with team and long injury hiatus

Main article: [2017 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2017 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

In January, Djokovic defended his title in [Doha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Qatar_ExxonMobil_Open "2017 Qatar ExxonMobil Open") after defeating the new world No. 1 [Andy Murray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray "Andy Murray"). At the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2017 Australian Open – Men's singles"), he was upset in the second round by world No. 117 [Denis Istomin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Istomin "Denis Istomin"). This was the first time since [2007](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2007 Australian Open – Men's singles") that Djokovic failed to reach the quarterfinals at the Australian Open, and the first time in his career that he lost to a player ranked outside of the top 100 at a major.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-268">[266]</a></sup> In February and March, Djokovic played at the [Mexican Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Abierto_Mexicano_Telcel_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2017 Abierto Mexicano Telcel – Men's singles") and [Indian Wells Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2017 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles"), but was eliminated by [Nick Kyrgios](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nick_Kyrgios "Nick Kyrgios") in both events before the semifinals. In April, Djokovic reached the quarterfinals of the [Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2017 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters – Singles"), losing to [David Goffin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Goffin "David Goffin"). After the tournament, he chose to split with his long-time coach [Marián Vajda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mari%C3%A1n_Vajda "Marián Vajda"), fitness specialist [Gebhard Phil-Gritsch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gebhard_Phil-Gritsch "Gebhard Phil-Gritsch"), and physiotherapist Miljan Amanović, citing the need to find a winning spark. A better showing at the [Madrid Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Mutua_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2017 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's singles") saw Djokovic reach the semifinals, losing to Nadal in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-269">[267]</a></sup> A runner-up result at the [Rome Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2017 Italian Open – Men's singles") indicated improvement in his form.

On 21 May 2017, Djokovic announced that [Andre Agassi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andre_Agassi "Andre Agassi") would become his new coach, starting at the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2017 French Open – Men's singles"). However, as the defending champion, he lost in the quarterfinals to [Dominic Thiem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominic_Thiem "Dominic Thiem").<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-270">[268]</a></sup> He began the grass court season at the [Eastbourne International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Aegon_International_Eastbourne_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2017 Aegon International Eastbourne – Men's singles"), playing his first non-Wimbledon tournament on grass since [2010](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Aegon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Singles "2010 Aegon Championships – Singles"). He won the title by beating [Gaël Monfils](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ga%C3%ABl_Monfils "Gaël Monfils") in the final. This was also the only tournament that Djokovic won without his coach being [Marián Vajda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mari%C3%A1n_Vajda "Marián Vajda") until the duo split in 2022. He made it to the quarterfinals at [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2017 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles") before retiring against [Tomáš Berdych](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom%C3%A1%C5%A1_Berdych "Tomáš Berdych") due to an elbow injury.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-271">[269]</a></sup>

On 26 July, Djokovic announced he would miss the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2017 US Open – Men's singles") and the rest of the 2017 season to recover from his elbow injury.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-272">[270]</a></sup> This was the first time that he missed a major tournament since he entered his first, the 2005 Australian Open, thus ending his streak of participating in 51 consecutive Grand Slam tournaments, the seventh-longest run in history.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-273">[271]</a></sup>

#### 2018: Surgery and resurgence; two Majors, return to No. 1 & historic Golden Masters

Main article: [2018 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2018 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

In January, Djokovic defeated [Dominic Thiem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominic_Thiem "Dominic Thiem") at the [Kooyong Classic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kooyong_Classic "Kooyong Classic") exhibition tournament. At the [2018 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 Australian Open – Men's singles"), he reached the fourth round, where he was upset by [Chung Hyeon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chung_Hyeon "Chung Hyeon"). In late January, he underwent surgery on his elbow.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-274">[272]</a></sup> On 3 March, Djokovic returned to the practice courts,<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-275">[273]</a></sup> and surprisingly played at [Indian Wells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles") only a week later, losing in the second round to [Taro Daniel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taro_Daniel "Taro Daniel").<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-276">[274]</a></sup> He then lost to [Benoît Paire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beno%C3%AEt_Paire "Benoît Paire") in the second round of the [Miami Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Miami_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 Miami Open – Men's singles").<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-277">[275]</a></sup>

Reuniting with longtime coach [Marián Vajda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mari%C3%A1n_Vajda "Marián Vajda") at the [Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Monte-Carlo_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2018 Monte-Carlo Masters – Singles"), Djokovic collected victories over [Dušan Lajović](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Du%C5%A1an_Lajovi%C4%87 "Dušan Lajović") and [Borna Ćorić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Borna_%C4%86ori%C4%87 "Borna Ćorić"), followed by a loss to Dominic Thiem. In a press conference, he stated, "After two years finally I can play without pain."<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-278">[276]</a></sup> After another early exit in [Barcelona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Barcelona_Open_Banco_Sabadell_%E2%80%93_Singles "2018 Barcelona Open Banco Sabadell – Singles") to [Martin Kližan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Kli%C5%BEan "Martin Kližan"),<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-279">[277]</a></sup> Djokovic's gradual return to form would appear at the [Madrid Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Mutua_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's singles"). With a first round win over [Kei Nishikori](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kei_Nishikori "Kei Nishikori"), Djokovic achieved his first victory over a top 20 player in 10 months; however, he lost in the second round to [Kyle Edmund](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyle_Edmund "Kyle Edmund").<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-280">[278]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-281">[279]</a></sup> Going into the [Rome Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 Italian Open – Men's singles") with a 6–6 season record, he reached the semifinals before losing to long-time rival [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal").<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-282">[280]</a></sup> He then reached the quarterfinals of the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 French Open – Men's singles") before losing to [Marco Cecchinato](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marco_Cecchinato "Marco Cecchinato").<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-283">[281]</a></sup>

Djokovic began the grass court season at [Queen's Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Queen%27s_Club_Championships_%E2%80%93_Singles "2018 Queen's Club Championships – Singles"), securing his first win over a top 5 player in almost 18 months by defeating [Grigor Dimitrov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grigor_Dimitrov "Grigor Dimitrov") in the second round. He reached the final where, despite holding a championship point, he lost to [Marin Čilić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marin_%C4%8Cili%C4%87 "Marin Čilić").<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-284">[282]</a></sup> He also played doubles partnering with longtime friend and rival [Stan Wawrinka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka "Stan Wawrinka"). Djokovic then entered [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles") as the 12th seed, where he reached the semifinals to face Rafael Nadal. Djokovic defeated Nadal in a 5-hour and 17-minute, five-set epic spread over two days, becoming the second-longest Wimbledon semifinal in history, second only to the match between [Kevin Anderson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Anderson_(tennis) "Kevin Anderson (tennis)") and [John Isner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Isner "John Isner") held earlier on the same day.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-285">[283]</a></sup> In the final, he claimed his fourth Wimbledon title and 13th major title overall by defeating Kevin Anderson in straight sets. With the win, he rose 11 ranking spots and re-entered the top 10 for the first time since October 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-286">[284]</a></sup> At No. 21, he was the lowest ranked Wimbledon titlist since [Goran Ivanišević](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goran_Ivani%C5%A1evi%C4%87 "Goran Ivanišević") in [2001](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2001_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2001 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles").<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-287">[285]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-288">[286]</a></sup>

After a triumphant grass season, Djokovic started his North American hardcourt swing with a third-round showing at the [Canadian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Rogers_Cup_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 Rogers Cup – Men's singles"), losing to [Stefanos Tsitsipas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stefanos_Tsitsipas "Stefanos Tsitsipas"). Afterwards, he returned to play the [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Western_%26_Southern_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 Western & Southern Open – Men's singles") for the first time in three years. In an event plagued by suspended play due to rain, Djokovic defeated the defending champion Grigor Dimitrov, [Milos Raonic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milos_Raonic "Milos Raonic"), and Marin Čilić to reach his sixth final at the tournament and fourth final against [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer"). Although Federer was riding a streak of 100 consecutive holds of serve at the tournament,<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-289">[287]</a></sup> dating back to the 2014 final,<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-290">[288]</a></sup> Djokovic broke his serve three times to win his first Cincinnati Masters title. With this victory, Djokovic became the first (and, as of 2022, only) player in tennis history to complete the [Career Golden Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_Masters_Series_singles_records_and_statistics#Career_Golden_Masters "Tennis Masters Series singles records and statistics") — winning all nine ATP Masters events at least once in one's career.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-291">[289]</a></sup>

Djokovic was the sixth seed at the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 US Open – Men's singles"). He advanced to his eleventh US Open semifinal in as many appearances, where he overcame Kei Nishikori. Djokovic then defeated [Juan Martín del Potro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Mart%C3%ADn_del_Potro "Juan Martín del Potro") to win his third US Open title and 14th major title overall, tying [Pete Sampras](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pete_Sampras "Pete Sampras")' tally. With the win, Djokovic returned to the top 3 in the world rankings for the first time since the 2017 French Open.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-292">[290]</a></sup>

At the [Shanghai Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2018 Shanghai Rolex Masters – Singles"), Djokovic defeated Kevin Anderson and [Alexander Zverev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Zverev "Alexander Zverev") en route to the title, not dropping a set nor having his serve broken throughout. The win marked his fourth Shanghai title, and his ranking rose to No. 2.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-293">[291]</a></sup> On 31 October, Rafael Nadal announced his withdrawal from the Paris Masters due to an abdominal injury, and Djokovic reclaimed the world No. 1 ranking.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-294">[292]</a></sup> There, Djokovic defeated Roger Federer in a tight three-set semifinal, but was upset by the unseeded [Karen Khachanov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karen_Khachanov "Karen Khachanov") in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-295">[293]</a></sup> At the [ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_ATP_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles "2018 ATP Finals – Singles"), Djokovic was guaranteed a fifth year-end No. 1 ranking following the withdrawal of Rafael Nadal from the event. In the round-robin stage, he defeated Alexander Zverev, Marin Čilić, and [John Isner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Isner "John Isner") without dropping a set. In the semifinals, he defeated Kevin Anderson to reach his seventh final at the tournament but was upset by Zverev.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-296">[294]</a></sup> At the [2018 Mubadala Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Mubadala_World_Tennis_Championship "2018 Mubadala World Tennis Championship"), he scored victories over Karen Khachanov & Kevin Anderson to win the title.

#### 2019: Historic 7th Australian Open title & Wimbledon title

Main article: [2019 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2019 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Novak_Djokovic_%2849745016006%29.jpg/200px-Novak_Djokovic_%2849745016006%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Novak_Djokovic_(49745016006).jpg)

Djokovic kissing Wimbledon trophy after winning the 2019 [Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2019 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles")

Djokovic's first tournament of the year was at the [Qatar Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Qatar_ExxonMobil_Open_%E2%80%93_Singles "2019 Qatar ExxonMobil Open – Singles"), where he lost to [Roberto Bautista Agut](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Bautista_Agut "Roberto Bautista Agut") in the semifinals. He then entered the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2019 Australian Open – Men's singles") as the top seed, and defeated [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal") in the final to win his record seventh Australian Open and 15th [major](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)#Tournaments "Grand Slam (tennis)") title overall.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-297">[295]</a></sup> Djokovic then played at the [Indian Wells Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2019 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles"), where he was upset by [Philipp Kohlschreiber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philipp_Kohlschreiber "Philipp Kohlschreiber") in the third round,<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-298">[296]</a></sup> and lost in the fourth round of the [Miami Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Miami_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2019 Miami Open – Men's singles") to Bautista Agut.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-299">[297]</a></sup>

Djokovic then began his clay court season at the [Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Monte-Carlo_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2019 Monte-Carlo Masters – Singles"), losing in the quarterfinals to [Daniil Medvedev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniil_Medvedev "Daniil Medvedev").<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-300">[298]</a></sup> During the [Madrid Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Mutua_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2019 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's singles"), Novak Djokovic celebrated his 250th week at [world number 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ATP_number_1_ranked_singles_tennis_players "List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players") in [ATP rankings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_rankings "ATP rankings").<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-301">[299]</a></sup> By beating [Stefanos Tsitsipas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stefanos_Tsitsipas "Stefanos Tsitsipas") in the final, Djokovic claimed his third Madrid Open title and record-equaling 33rd ATP Masters title overall.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-302">[300]</a></sup> At the [Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2019 Italian Open – Men's singles"), he reached the final after a brutal victory over long time rival [Juan Martín del Potro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Mart%C3%ADn_del_Potro "Juan Martín del Potro"),<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-303">[301]</a></sup> where he lost to Rafael Nadal.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-304">[302]</a></sup> Djokovic competed in the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2019 French Open – Men's singles"), reaching the semifinals without dropping a set. His fourth-round win made him the first man to reach 10 consecutive quarterfinals at the French Open. In the semifinals, he lost to [Dominic Thiem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominic_Thiem "Dominic Thiem") in a four-hour, five-set match stretched across two days, in one of the matches of the year,<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-305">[303]</a></sup> ending his 26-match winning streak in majors and his search for a second 'Nole Slam".<sup id="cite_ref-Thiem_306-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Thiem-306">[304]</a></sup>

At [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2019 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles"), Djokovic defended his title to win his fifth Wimbledon title and 16th major title overall, defeating [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer") in an epic five-set [final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final "2019 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles final") that lasted a record four hours and fifty-seven minutes. Djokovic, who won fewer points overall than Federer, saved two championship points in the fifth set to win the title.<sup id="cite_ref-wimbledon2019_307-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-wimbledon2019-307">[305]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-308">[306]</a></sup> Djokovic next played at the [Cincinnati Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Western_%26_Southern_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2019 Western & Southern Open – Men's singles") as the defending champion, but lost to eventual champion Daniil Medvedev in the semifinals.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-309">[307]</a></sup> As the defending champion at the [2019 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2019 US Open – Men's singles"), Djokovic lost to [Stan Wawrinka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka "Stan Wawrinka") in the fourth round, retiring due to injury whilst trailing by 2 sets and a break.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-310">[308]</a></sup> In October, Djokovic defeated [John Millman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Millman "John Millman") in straight sets to win the [Japan Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Rakuten_Japan_Open_Tennis_Championships_%E2%80%93_Singles "2019 Rakuten Japan Open Tennis Championships – Singles").<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-311">[309]</a></sup> At the [Shanghai Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Rolex_Shanghai_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2019 Rolex Shanghai Masters – Singles"), Djokovic reached the quarterfinal stage, but lost to Stefanos Tsitsipas.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-312">[310]</a></sup> In November, Djokovic won his fifth [Paris Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Rolex_Paris_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2019 Rolex Paris Masters – Singles") title over [Denis Shapovalov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Shapovalov "Denis Shapovalov").<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-313">[311]</a></sup> Djokovic then played at the [2019 ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_ATP_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles "2019 ATP Finals – Singles") but was eliminated in the round robin stage after losses to Dominic Thiem and Federer (his first loss to Federer since 2015).<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-314">[312]</a></sup>

### 2020s

#### 2020: ATP Cup crown, Australian Open title & double Golden Masters

Main article: [2020 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2020 Novak Djokovic tennis season")
