At the inaugural [2020 ATP Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_ATP_Cup "2020 ATP Cup"), Djokovic led Serbia to the title by scoring six victories, including wins over [Daniil Medvedev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniil_Medvedev "Daniil Medvedev") in the semifinals and [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal") in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-315">[313]</a></sup> At the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2020 Australian Open – Men's singles"), he defeated [longtime rival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Djokovic%E2%80%93Federer_rivalry "Djokovic–Federer rivalry") [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer") in straight sets en route to the final where he overcame [Dominic Thiem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominic_Thiem "Dominic Thiem") in five sets. This marked Djokovic's eighth win at the Australian Open and 17th [Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)#Tournaments "Grand Slam (tennis)") title.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-316">[314]</a></sup> With the win, Djokovic regained the world No. 1 spot in the ATP rankings,<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-317">[315]</a></sup> and became the first player since [Ken Rosewall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ken_Rosewall "Ken Rosewall") to win major titles in three different decades, and the first to do so in the [Open Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Era "Open Era"). The match also marked the first time Djokovic came back to win a major final after trailing two sets to one, having lost each of the last seven times this happened.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-318">[316]</a></sup> Djokovic then won the title at [Dubai Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Dubai_Tennis_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2020 Dubai Tennis Championships – Men's singles") for the fifth time, defeating [Stefanos Tsitsipas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stefanos_Tsitsipas "Stefanos Tsitsipas") in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-319">[317]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-320">[318]</a></sup>

In June, Djokovic tested positive for [COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coronavirus_disease_2019 "Coronavirus disease 2019") during the [Adria Tour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adria_Tour "Adria Tour"), a series of charity exhibition games in Balkans that he helped organize. Djokovic was criticized for holding the event with a lack of social distancing and other precautions taken against COVID-19.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-321">[319]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-322">[320]</a></sup> The last match of the tour was cancelled after several players, their partners, and coaches tested positive for the virus.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-323">[321]</a></sup> Djokovic stated he was "deeply sorry", admitting he and organisers "were wrong" to go ahead with the event and that they believed the tournament met all health protocols.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-324">[322]</a></sup> He also said that many of the criticisms were malicious, adding: "It's obviously more than just criticism, it's like an agenda and a witch hunt".<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-325">[323]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-326">[324]</a></sup>

With the resumption of the ATP Tour, Djokovic defeated [Milos Raonic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milos_Raonic "Milos Raonic") to win his second [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Western_%26_Southern_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2020 Western & Southern Open – Men's singles") title. By doing so, he won his 35th [Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Tour_Masters_1000 "ATP Tour Masters 1000") title, completing his second [career Golden Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_Masters_Series_singles_records_and_statistics#Career_Golden_Masters "Tennis Masters Series singles records and statistics").<sup id="cite_ref-DGM_327-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-DGM-327">[325]</a></sup> In the fourth round of the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2020 US Open – Men's singles"), Djokovic was defaulted after accidentally hitting a line official in the throat with a tennis ball during his fourth round match against [Pablo Carreño Busta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pablo_Carre%C3%B1o_Busta "Pablo Carreño Busta").<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-328">[326]</a></sup> The [United States Tennis Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Tennis_Association "United States Tennis Association") docked Djokovic all ranking points he would have earned at the tournament and fined him the prize money that he would have won had the incident not occurred.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-329">[327]</a></sup> On 21 September, Djokovic moved past [Pete Sampras](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pete_Sampras "Pete Sampras") for the second most weeks spent as the [world number 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Era_tennis_records_%E2%80%93_men%27s_singles#ATP_rankings_achievements "Open Era tennis records – men's singles") player.

Djokovic next won a record 36th Masters title and his fifth in [Rome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2020 Italian Open – Men's singles"), defeating [Diego Schwartzman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Schwartzman "Diego Schwartzman") in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-330">[328]</a></sup> At the rescheduled [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2020 French Open – Men's singles"), Djokovic lost in straight sets to Rafael Nadal in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-331">[329]</a></sup> Djokovic then played at the [Vienna Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Erste_Bank_Open_%E2%80%93_Singles "2020 Erste Bank Open – Singles"), where he was upset in the quarterfinals by [Lorenzo Sonego](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lorenzo_Sonego "Lorenzo Sonego") in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-332">[330]</a></sup> In the [ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_ATP_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles "2020 ATP Finals – Singles"), Djokovic lost to [Daniil Medvedev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniil_Medvedev "Daniil Medvedev") in the round robin, but defeated [Alexander Zverev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Zverev "Alexander Zverev") and [Diego Schwartzman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Schwartzman "Diego Schwartzman"). He then lost his semifinal match to [Dominic Thiem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominic_Thiem "Dominic Thiem").<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-333">[331]</a></sup> On 21 December, Djokovic reached his 300th career week as the [number 1 singles tennis player](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ATP_number_1_ranked_singles_tennis_players "List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players").<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-334">[332]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-335">[333]</a></sup>

#### 2021: Major titles on all three surfaces, historic double Career Slam & No. 1 records

Main article: [2021 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2021 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

Djokovic began his 2021 season by playing for Serbia as the defending champions in the [ATP Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_ATP_Cup "2021 ATP Cup"), but the nation was eliminated in the group stage despite Djokovic winning both his singles matches.<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-336">[334]</a></sup> He then went on to win his 18th major title and record-extending ninth title at the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2021 Australian Open – Men's singles"), over Daniil Medvedev in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-337">[335]</a></sup> On 1 March, Djokovic equaled Federer's Open Era record of 310 weeks at world No. 1, and subsequently surpassed it. As of 23 May 2022 the weeks at number one stands at 371.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-338">[336]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-339">[337]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-no1_340-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-no1-340">[338]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-341">[339]</a></sup> Djokovic next played at the [Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Monte-Carlo_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2021 Monte-Carlo Masters – Singles"), where he lost his third round match to [Dan Evans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_Evans_(tennis) "Dan Evans (tennis)").<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-342">[340]</a></sup> Djokovic then played at the [Serbia Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Serbia_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2021 Serbia Open – Men's singles"), losing a lengthy three-set semifinal to [Aslan Karatsev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aslan_Karatsev "Aslan Karatsev").<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-343">[341]</a></sup> At the [Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2021 Italian Open – Men's singles"), Djokovic defeated Stefanos Tsitsipas in a three-set epic played over two days in the quarterfinals,<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-344">[342]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-345">[343]</a></sup> and [Lorenzo Sonego](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lorenzo_Sonego "Lorenzo Sonego") in the semifinals, but lost in a three-set final to Rafael Nadal.

At the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2021 French Open – Men's singles"), Djokovic advanced to the final after defeating Rafael Nadal in a four-set semifinal epic. It marked only Nadal's second loss to Djokovic (and third loss overall) at the event. In the final, Djokovic came back from two sets down to defeat [Stefanos Tsitsipas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stefanos_Tsitsipas "Stefanos Tsitsipas") in five sets.<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-346">[344]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-347">[345]</a></sup> He became the first player in the Open Era to win a Major after coming back from a two-set deficit in two separate matches;<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-348">[346]</a></sup> Djokovic also became only the third man to [win all four singles majors at least twice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Grand_Slam_men%27s_singles_champions#Career_Grand_Slam "List of Grand Slam men's singles champions"), and the first to do so in the [Open Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Era "Open Era").<sup id="cite_ref-DCGS_349-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-DCGS-349">[347]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-350">[348]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DETS_351-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-DETS-351">[349]</a></sup>

At the [2021 Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2021 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles"), Djokovic recorded the 100th grass-court win by reaching the semifinals,<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-352">[350]</a></sup> and defeated [Matteo Berrettini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matteo_Berrettini "Matteo Berrettini") in the final to claim his sixth Wimbledon title and equal Federer and Nadal's all-time [record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Grand_Slam_men%27s_singles_champions#Champions_list "List of Grand Slam men's singles champions") of 20 men's singles major titles. Djokovic became the second player to win Majors on three different surfaces in the same year achieving a "Surface Slam"<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-353">[351]</a></sup> and the fifth man in the Open Era to achieve the "Channel Slam", winning the French Open and Wimbledon in the same year.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-354">[352]</a></sup> Djokovic opened his summer hard court season at the [Tokyo Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "Tennis at the 2020 Summer Olympics – Men's singles"), where he sought to improve on his [bronze medal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bronze_medal "Bronze medal") result from [Beijing 2008](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "Tennis at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's singles").<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-355">[353]</a></sup> However, he lost in the semifinals to [Alexander Zverev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Zverev "Alexander Zverev"), and then to [Pablo Carreño Busta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pablo_Carre%C3%B1o_Busta "Pablo Carreño Busta") in the bronze medal match. Djokovic also competed in [mixed doubles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Mixed_doubles "Tennis at the 2020 Summer Olympics – Mixed doubles") partnering [Nina Stojanović](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nina_Stojanovi%C4%87 "Nina Stojanović"); the pair lost in the semifinals to [Aslan Karatsev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aslan_Karatsev "Aslan Karatsev") and [Elena Vesnina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elena_Vesnina "Elena Vesnina"), then withdrew from their bronze medal match against WTA singles No. 1 [Ashleigh Barty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashleigh_Barty "Ashleigh Barty") and [John Peers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Peers "John Peers"), with Djokovic citing a shoulder injury.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-356">[354]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-357">[355]</a></sup>

Djokovic then entered the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2021 US Open – Men's singles") vying to be the third man in history to achieve the [Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)#Grand_Slam "Grand Slam (tennis)") in men's singles.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-358">[356]</a></sup> In the third round, Djokovic faced [Kei Nishikori](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kei_Nishikori "Kei Nishikori") and lost the first set, but won the next three sets to advance; he repeated this pattern against [Jenson Brooksby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jenson_Brooksby "Jenson Brooksby")<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-359">[357]</a></sup> and Matteo Berrettini. In the semifinals, he defeated Alexander Zverev in five sets, to advance to his record-equaling 31st major final.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-360">[358]</a></sup> There, he faced [Daniil Medvedev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniil_Medvedev "Daniil Medvedev") but lost in straight sets, ending his chances of achieving the Grand Slam.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-361">[359]</a></sup>

At the [Paris Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Rolex_Paris_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2021 Rolex Paris Masters – Singles"), Djokovic defeated [Hubert Hurkacz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubert_Hurkacz "Hubert Hurkacz") to reach the final, which secured the year-end No. 1 ranking for the seventh time, breaking [Pete Sampras](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pete_Sampras "Pete Sampras")' all-time record. In the final, he avenged his US Open loss to Daniil Medvedev to win his sixth Paris Masters title and record 37th [ATP Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Masters_1000 "ATP Masters 1000") title overall.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-362">[360]</a></sup> At the [2021 ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_ATP_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles "2021 ATP Finals – Singles"), Djokovic was defeated in the semifinals by Zverev.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-363">[361]</a></sup> Djokovic finished the season by leading [Serbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia_men%27s_national_tennis_team "Serbia men's national tennis team") to the semifinals of [2021 Davis Cup Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Davis_Cup_Finals "2021 Davis Cup Finals"), where they lost to [Croatia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Croatia_men%27s_national_tennis_team "Croatia men's national tennis team").<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-364">[362]</a></sup>

#### 2022: Travel restrictions, Wimbledon title, record 38th Masters & 6th Year-end Championship

Main article: [2022 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2022 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

##### Australian Open controversy

See also: [§ Opposition to COVID-19 vaccine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#Opposition_to_COVID-19_vaccine)

Djokovic was set to begin his 2022 season by participating in the [ATP Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_ATP_Cup "2022 ATP Cup") in Sydney but pulled out.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-365">[363]</a></sup> In order to play at the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 Australian Open – Men's singles"), where he was a three-time defending champion, the Victorian Government required all players to be vaccinated against [COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19 "COVID-19") or have a medical exemption. Djokovic was one of "a handful" of players and staff to be granted a medical exemption by [Tennis Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_Australia "Tennis Australia") and the [Department of Health in Victoria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Department_of_Health_(Victoria) "Department of Health (Victoria)").<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-366">[364]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-367">[365]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dw22_368-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-dw22-368">[366]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-369">[367]</a></sup> It was later revealed that Djokovic tested positive for COVID-19 on 16 December 2021 which was used as the basis for his exemption.<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-370">[368]</a></sup>

Djokovic had been granted a visa to enter Australia on 18 November 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-371">[369]</a></sup> He travelled to Melbourne on 5 January but was detained by the [Australian Border Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Border_Force "Australian Border Force") after they determined that he did not meet the entry requirements for an unvaccinated traveller.<sup id="cite_ref-gre22_372-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-gre22-372">[370]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-waka22_373-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-waka22-373">[371]</a></sup> Djokovic disclosed that a member of his support team ticked a box on his application form stating he had not travelled abroad two weeks before he left for Australia; however, he had been to Spain at that time.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-374">[372]</a></sup> His visa was cancelled and he was held in an immigration detention hotel for several days awaiting a court hearing.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-375">[373]</a></sup>

On 10 January, the [Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Circuit_and_Family_Court_of_Australia "Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia") ordered his release and [awarded costs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Court_costs "Court costs"),<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-376">[374]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-377">[375]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-docket_378-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-docket-378">[376]</a></sup> ruling that the visa cancelation process undertaken by Australian border officials was flawed on the basis that they did not give Djokovic sufficient time to contact his lawyers and tennis authorities before his official interview. The [Australian Government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Government "Australian Government") conceded that the cancelation was "unreasonable in \[the\] circumstances".<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-379">[377]</a></sup>

On 14 January 2022, [Alex Hawke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Hawke "Alex Hawke"), Australia's [Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minister_for_Immigration,_Citizenship,_Migrant_Services_and_Multicultural_Affairs "Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs"), exercised his ministerial powers under sections 133C(3) and 116(1)(e)(i) of the _[Migration Act 1958](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Migration_Act_1958 "Migration Act 1958")_ to cancel Djokovic's visa,<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-380">[378]</a></sup> citing "health and good order grounds, on the basis that it was in the public interest to do so".<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-381">[379]</a></sup> Djokovic applied for a [judicial review](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_administrative_law#judicial_review "Australian administrative law"), but three [Federal Court of Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Court_of_Australia "Federal Court of Australia") judges unanimously dismissed his application on 16 January, preventing his participation in the 2022 Australian Open.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-382">[380]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-383">[381]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-allsop-j-et-al-2022_384-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-allsop-j-et-al-2022-384">[382]</a></sup> Djokovic said he was "extremely disappointed" with the decision but accepted the ruling, and flew out of Australia to [Dubai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dubai_International_Airport "Dubai International Airport") that night.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-385">[383]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-386">[384]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-afp-20220117-dubai_387-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-afp-20220117-dubai-387">[385]</a></sup> Because he was removed using ministerial powers under the _Migration Act_, he is now barred from returning to Australia for three years,<sup id="cite_ref-abc22_388-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-abc22-388">[386]</a></sup> although each visa application is reviewed on its merits.<sup id="cite_ref-abc22_388-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-abc22-388">[386]</a></sup> As of November 2022, this visa ban has been overturned by the [recently elected](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Australian_federal_election "2022 Australian federal election") Immigration Minister [Andrew Giles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Giles "Andrew Giles").<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-389">[387]</a></sup>

In February, Djokovic gave an interview to the [BBC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC "BBC") regarding his deportation from Australia, stating he is willing to forego career records by sticking to his principles of free choice and not having the COVID-19 vaccine.<sup id="cite_ref-willing_14-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-willing-14">[12]</a></sup> In May, he admitted that the court battle and his deportation from Australia "took a major toll" on him.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-390">[388]</a></sup> He said: "The amount of pressure and everything that I was feeling in the first few months of the year, as much as I've felt pressure in my life and my career, that was something really on a whole different level".<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-391">[389]</a></sup>

##### After Australia

Djokovic entered the [Dubai Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Dubai_Tennis_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 Dubai Tennis Championships – Men's singles") in February, where vaccination was not required for entry.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-392">[390]</a></sup> He was upset in the quarterfinals by eventual finalist [Jiří Veselý](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ji%C5%99%C3%AD_Vesel%C3%BD "Jiří Veselý"), resulting in him conceding his [world No. 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ATP_number_1_ranked_singles_tennis_players "List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players") ranking to [Daniil Medvedev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniil_Medvedev "Daniil Medvedev"). This marked the first time a man outside of the [Big Four](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Four_(tennis) "Big Four (tennis)") was ranked singles world No. 1 since [Andy Roddick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Roddick "Andy Roddick") in February 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-393">[391]</a></sup> Djokovic withdrew from both the [Indian Wells Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles") and the [Miami Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Miami_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 Miami Open – Men's singles"), due to the United States [forbidding unvaccinated foreign travellers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States "COVID-19 pandemic in the United States").<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-394">[392]</a></sup> Despite being unable to play, Djokovic regained the world No. 1 ranking after Medvedev's third-round defeat at Indian Wells.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-395">[393]</a></sup>

After being unable to play in March, Djokovic began his clay court season at the [Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Monte-Carlo_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2022 Monte-Carlo Masters – Singles") in April. Seeded first, he received a bye in the first round and lost to eventual finalist [Davidovich Fokina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alejandro_Davidovich_Fokina "Alejandro Davidovich Fokina") in the second, his first opening match loss since the [2018 Barcelona Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Barcelona_Open_Banco_Sabadell_%E2%80%93_Singles "2018 Barcelona Open Banco Sabadell – Singles").<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-396">[394]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-397">[395]</a></sup> Later that month, he reached the final of the [Serbia Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Serbia_Open_%E2%80%93_Singles "2022 Serbia Open – Singles") and lost to [Andrey Rublev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrey_Rublev "Andrey Rublev") in three sets.<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-398">[396]</a></sup> At the [Madrid Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Mutua_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's singles") in May, Djokovic made it to the semifinals where he was beaten in three sets by 19-year-old [Carlos Alcaraz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Alcaraz "Carlos Alcaraz"), the eventual champion.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-399">[397]</a></sup> At the [Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 Italian Open – Men's singles") a week later, he reached the twelfth final of his career at this Masters. In the semifinals, he defeated [Casper Ruud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Casper_Ruud "Casper Ruud") for his 1,000th career win, becoming only the fifth man in the Open Era to reach this milestone.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-400">[398]</a></sup> In the final, he defeated [Stefanos Tsitsipas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stefanos_Tsitsipas "Stefanos Tsitsipas") in straight sets to win his sixth [Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Open_(tennis) "Italian Open (tennis)") and record-extending 38th Masters title.<sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-401">[399]</a></sup>

Djokovic entered the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 French Open – Men's singles") in May as the defending champion. After defeating [Yoshihito Nishioka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshihito_Nishioka "Yoshihito Nishioka"), [Alex Molčan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Mol%C4%8Dan "Alex Molčan"), [Aljaž Bedene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alja%C5%BE_Bedene "Aljaž Bedene") and [Diego Schwartzman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Schwartzman "Diego Schwartzman") in straight sets, he faced [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal") in the quarterfinals for their [record-extending 59th meeting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Djokovic%E2%80%93Nadal_rivalry "Djokovic–Nadal rivalry"). He lost in four sets, ending his French Open title defense.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-402">[400]</a></sup> As a result of his quarterfinals defeat, he conceded the No. 1 ranking to [Daniil Medvedev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniil_Medvedev "Daniil Medvedev") for the second time in 2022.

With his first-round win at the [Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles") against [Kwon Soon-woo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kwon_Soon-woo "Kwon Soon-woo"), Djokovic became the first player in history (male or female) to win 80 matches at all four majors.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-403">[401]</a></sup> With his semifinal win over [Cameron Norrie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cameron_Norrie "Cameron Norrie"), Djokovic reached a record 32nd Grand Slam final, one ahead of [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer").<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-404">[402]</a></sup> Djokovic went on to defeat [Nick Kyrgios](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nick_Kyrgios "Nick Kyrgios") in the final in four sets for his fourth consecutive and seventh overall Wimbledon trophy.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-405">[403]</a></sup> With this victory, he reached a total of 21 major titles, which broke his tie of 20 majors with Federer and put him one Grand Slam title behind Nadal.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-406">[404]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-407">[405]</a></sup>

Due to Djokovic's unvaccinated status against COVID-19, he was unable to compete in the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_US_Open_(tennis) "2022 US Open (tennis)") as the [US government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government of the United States") did not allow unvaccinated non-US [citizens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship "Citizenship") to enter the country.<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-408">[406]</a></sup> As a result, he withdrew from the tournament on 25 August.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-409">[407]</a></sup> At the [Astana Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Astana_Open "2022 Astana Open") in October, he defeated Medvedev in the semifinals and [Stefanos Tsitsipas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stefanos_Tsitsipas "Stefanos Tsitsipas") in the final to win his 90th singles title.<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-410">[408]</a></sup> Djokovic then competed at the [Paris Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Rolex_Paris_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2022 Rolex Paris Masters – Singles"), where he defeated Stefanos Tsitsipas in the semifinals to reach his third straight final of the season. It was also the 650th hard-court win of his career, making him just the third male player in the [Open Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Era "Open Era") to record 650 or more career wins on any single surface.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-411">[409]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-412">[410]</a></sup> He then lost in the final to 19-year-old [Holger Rune](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holger_Rune "Holger Rune"), which marked the first time Djokovic lost a Masters finals after winning the first set.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-413">[411]</a></sup>

Seeded seventh at the [ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_ATP_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles "2022 ATP Finals – Singles"), Djokovic won his first round robin match over second seed Stefanos Tsitsipas to record his 60th career victory over a Top 3 player, making him the first player to accomplish this milestone since the ATP rankings began in 1973.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-414">[412]</a></sup> Djokovic then defeated sixth seed [Andrey Rublev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrey_Rublev "Andrey Rublev") and fourth seed [Daniil Medvedev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniil_Medvedev "Daniil Medvedev") to reach the semifinals, where he defeated [Taylor Fritz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taylor_Fritz "Taylor Fritz") to reach his eighth final at this event and secured his 15th year-end top-5 finish in the rankings.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-415">[413]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-416">[414]</a></sup> He defeated Casper Ruud to win a record-equaling sixth ATP Finals title.<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-417">[415]</a></sup> He is also the first player ever to win the ATP Finals in three different decades—the 2000s, 2010s and 2020s.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-418">[416]</a></sup> Djokovic, at the age of 35, also became the oldest champion in the ATP Finals' 53-year history.<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-419">[417]</a></sup>

#### 2023: Historic 23rd, 24th and triple Career Slam, record Year-end 7th championship and 8th world No. 1

Main article: [2023 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2023 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/2023RGNovakDjokovic_%28cropped%29.jpg/200px-2023RGNovakDjokovic_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2023RGNovakDjokovic_(cropped).jpg)

Djokovic at the [2023 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_French_Open "2023 French Open")

Djokovic started his season by winning his 92nd career title at the [2023 Adelaide International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Adelaide_International_1 "2023 Adelaide International 1"), where he defeated [Sebastian Korda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sebastian_Korda "Sebastian Korda") in three sets in the final after saving a championship point.<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-420">[418]</a></sup> At the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2023 Australian Open – Men's singles"),<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-421">[419]</a></sup> Djokovic overcame hamstring injury concerns<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-422">[420]</a></sup> to reach the final, where he defeated [Stefanos Tsitsipas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stefanos_Tsitsipas "Stefanos Tsitsipas") in straight sets to claim his record-extending [10th Australian Open title](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Australian_Open_men%27s_singles_champions "List of Australian Open men's singles champions") while tying Nadal for the [record of 22 men's singles major titles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Era_tennis_records_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "Open Era tennis records – Men's singles") and reclaiming the world No. 1 ranking from [Carlos Alcaraz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Alcaraz "Carlos Alcaraz").<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-423">[421]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-424">[422]</a></sup> On 27 February 2023, Djokovic broke [Steffi Graf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steffi_Graf "Steffi Graf")'s record of 377 weeks that she set back 25 years ago for most weeks as world No. 1 in women's tennis, thus he became the player with most weeks at No. 1 on both the men's and women's tours.<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-425">[423]</a></sup>

In March, Djokovic withdrew from the [Indian Wells Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_BNP_Paribas_Open "2023 BNP Paribas Open") and [Miami Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Miami_Open "2023 Miami Open") after being denied a visa into the United States due to being unvaccinated. Afterwards, Djokovic struggled in the clay court season, suffering early defeats at the [Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Monte-Carlo_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2023 Monte-Carlo Masters – Singles")<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-426">[424]</a></sup> and the [Banja Luka Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Srpska_Open "2023 Srpska Open").<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-427">[425]</a></sup> At the [Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2023 Italian Open – Men's singles"), Djokovic was defeated in the quarterfinals by [Holger Rune](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holger_Rune "Holger Rune").<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-428">[426]</a></sup>

At the [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2023 French Open – Men's singles"), he returned to form, reaching the semifinals to face world No. 1 [Carlos Alcaraz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Alcaraz "Carlos Alcaraz"), whom he defeated in four sets to reach a record-extending 34th major final. Moreover, he became the only player to contest at least seven finals at each Grand Slam tournament. Djokovic would go on to beat [Casper Ruud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Casper_Ruud "Casper Ruud") in the final, securing a record-breaking 23rd major title and becoming the first man in tennis history to achieve a [triple Career Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)#Career_Grand_Slam "Grand Slam (tennis)").<sup id="cite_ref-slamrecord_429-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-slamrecord-429">[427]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23majors_18-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-23majors-18">[16]</a></sup> By winning the title, Djokovic reclaimed the world No. 1 position from Alcaraz.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-430">[428]</a></sup>

Djokovic then played at the [2023 Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2023 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles") where he was bidding to win a fifth consecutive title and a record-equalling eighth title. He reached the semifinals with straight set victories over [Pedro Cachin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedro_Cachin "Pedro Cachin"), [Jordan Thompson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_Thompson_(tennis) "Jordan Thompson (tennis)") and Stan Wawrinka, and four set victories over [Hubert Hurkacz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubert_Hurkacz "Hubert Hurkacz") and [Andrey Rublev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrey_Rublev "Andrey Rublev"). In the semifinals, he faced [Jannik Sinner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jannik_Sinner "Jannik Sinner") in a rematch of their quarterfinal match the previous year, and Djokovic won in straight sets to reach his 5th consecutive and 9th overall Wimbledon final, as well as his record-extending 35th major final, where he faced Carlos Alcaraz.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-431">[429]</a></sup> He subsequently lost [an epic final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final "2023 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles final") to Alcaraz in five sets, ending his 34-match winning streak at Wimbledon since [2018](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles") and his unbeaten run in both Wimbledon finals and [Centre Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centre_Court "Centre Court") since his [2013](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final "2013 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles final") defeat to [Andy Murray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray "Andy Murray").<sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-432">[430]</a></sup>

He proceeded to win his third [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Western_%26_Southern_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2023 Western & Southern Open – Men's singles") title and a record-extending 39th Masters title. He beat Alcaraz in a rematch of their Wimbledon final, in what was the longest best-of-three-sets ATP final and the longest match in the tournament's history, at 3 hours and 49 minutes, and was immediately praised as one of the best matches of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-:82_433-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:82-433">[431]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:9_434-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:9-434">[432]</a></sup> He won the match from a set down and down a break in the second set, along with saving a championship point in the second-set tiebreaker.<sup id="cite_ref-:82_433-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:82-433">[431]</a></sup> Djokovic called it one of his toughest matches, and said "It did feel like a Grand Slam final, even more than that to be honest". He compared the intensity and toughness of the match to his match against [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal") in the [2012 Australian Open final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final "2012 Australian Open – Men's singles final").<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-435">[433]</a></sup>

Djokovic then played at the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2023 US Open – Men's singles") where he dropped only two sets en route to the title, both to his fellow countryman [Laslo Djere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laslo_Djere "Laslo Djere") in a win from two sets down in the third round.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-436">[434]</a></sup> By reaching a 47th men's singles major semifinal, Djokovic surpassed Roger Federer's Open Era [record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Grand_Slam%E2%80%93related_tennis_records#Singles_career_totals_(all_time) "List of Grand Slam–related tennis records").<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-437">[435]</a></sup> By reaching the final, Djokovic matched Federer's record of reaching all major finals in a season three times. In the final, he faced [Daniil Medvedev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniil_Medvedev "Daniil Medvedev") in a rematch of their [2021 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2021 US Open – Men's singles") final. Djokovic defeated Medvedev in straight sets to win his fourth [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Open_(tennis) "US Open (tennis)") title and a record-extending 24th men's singles [major](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)#Tournaments "Grand Slam (tennis)") title overall, also equaling [Margaret Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaret_Court "Margaret Court")'s all-time record of major singles titles by either sex.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-438">[436]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-439">[437]</a></sup> Djokovic became the oldest US Open men's singles champion in the Open Era, at 36 years and 111 days,<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-440">[438]</a></sup> and became the first man to win three majors in a season four times.<sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-441">[439]</a></sup> By winning his first-round match, Djokovic guaranteed that he would reclaim the world No. 1 position from Alcaraz at the end of the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-442">[440]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-443">[441]</a></sup> With Djokovic reaching the final and winning, at the time, he had won one-third of all majors he played in and reached the final in half of the majors he played in.<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-444">[442]</a></sup>

After a six-week break, Djokovic returned to the tour at the [Paris Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Rolex_Paris_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2023 Rolex Paris Masters – Singles"), where he won his second round match over [Tomás Martín Etcheverry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom%C3%A1s_Mart%C3%ADn_Etcheverry "Tomás Martín Etcheverry") in his 1289th career match, surpassing [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal") for the fourth most in the [Open Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Era "Open Era").<sup id="cite_ref-445" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-445">[443]</a></sup> He went on to defeat [Grigor Dimitrov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grigor_Dimitrov "Grigor Dimitrov") in the final to win his record-extending seventh Paris Masters title and 40th Masters overall.<sup id="cite_ref-paris-2023_446-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-paris-2023-446">[444]</a></sup> By winning his first round robin match over [Holger Rune](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holger_Rune "Holger Rune") at the [2023 ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_ATP_Finals "2023 ATP Finals"), he secured the [Year-end world No. 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ATP_number_1_ranked_singles_tennis_players#Year-end_No._1_players "List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players") for a record-extending eighth time.<sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-447">[445]</a></sup> Djokovic then defeated second seed Alcaraz to reach his ninth final at this event, where he beat home favourite [Jannik Sinner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jannik_Sinner "Jannik Sinner") to win a record-breaking seventh ATP Finals title.<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-448">[446]</a></sup> This victory saw him become the first World No. 1 to win this event since [Andy Murray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray "Andy Murray") in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-449">[447]</a></sup> Despite playing in only 12 tournaments, Djokovic led the tour in titles won with seven, the most he has claimed in a season since 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-450">[448]</a></sup> On 20 November, Djokovic became the first player in singles to reach 400 weeks at No. 1.<sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-451">[449]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-452" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-452">[450]</a></sup>

#### 2024: Oldest ATP No. 1 and 1100th tour level win

Main article: [2024 Novak Djokovic tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Novak_Djokovic_tennis_season "2024 Novak Djokovic tennis season")

In a bid to win his 25th major title at the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2024 Australian Open – Men's singles"), Djokovic reached the semifinals against world No. 4 [Jannik Sinner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jannik_Sinner "Jannik Sinner"). There he lost in four sets for his first loss at the Australian Open since 2018, his first-ever Australian Open semifinal loss, and his third loss to Sinner in a three-month span, ending his consecutive win streak of 33 wins. By reaching a 58th major singles quarterfinal, Djokovic equaled [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer")'s [all-time record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Grand_Slam_and_related_tennis_records#Singles_career_totals_(all_time) "List of Grand Slam and related tennis records").<sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-453">[451]</a></sup> Despite the loss, he retained the world No. 1 ranking. In March, Djokovic returned to the [Indian Wells Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_BNP_Paribas_Open "2024 BNP Paribas Open"), for the first time since 2019, there he was beaten in the third round by lucky loser and world No. 123 [Luca Nardi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luca_Nardi "Luca Nardi"), in three sets. Nardi became the lowest ranked player to defeat Djokovic in any Masters 1000 tournament or Grand Slam event in his career. At the [2024 Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Monte-Carlo_Masters "2024 Monte-Carlo Masters"), Djokovic advanced to the semifinals, but was defeated by [Casper Ruud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Casper_Ruud "Casper Ruud") in three sets. After his win against [Corentin Moutet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corentin_Moutet "Corentin Moutet") at the [Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Italian_Open_(tennis) "2024 Italian Open (tennis)"), Djokovic got hit by an aluminum water bottle while signing autographs which struck him on the head.<sup id="cite_ref-454" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-454">[452]</a></sup> He then lost to [Alejandro Tabilo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alejandro_Tabilo "Alejandro Tabilo") in straight sets in the third round. At the [2024 Geneva Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Geneva_Open "2024 Geneva Open") where he was a late wildcard entry, he reached his 1100th career win on his 37th birthday after defeating [Yannick Hanfmann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yannick_Hanfmann "Yannick Hanfmann") in the second round. He became only the third player in the [Open Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Era "Open Era") to reach the milestone after [Jimmy Connors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Connors "Jimmy Connors") and [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer"). With a 1,100-218 win-loss record, at 83.5% he recorded the best winning percentage for a man in the Open Era.<sup id="cite_ref-455" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-455">[453]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-456">[454]</a></sup>

## Rivalries

See also: [Big Three (tennis)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Three_(tennis) "Big Three (tennis)") and [List of tennis rivalries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tennis_rivalries "List of tennis rivalries")

Djokovic has a winning record against all of his top contemporaries, including his fellow [Big Three](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Three_(tennis) "Big Three (tennis)") counterparts, [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer") and [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal").

### Rafael Nadal

Main article: [Djokovic–Nadal rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Djokovic%E2%80%93Nadal_rivalry "Djokovic–Nadal rivalry")

Djokovic and [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal") rivalry is the most prolific in men's tennis in the [Open Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Era "Open Era"). The two have faced each other 59 times, including in all four major finals, with Djokovic leading 30–29 overall.<sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-457">[455]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-458" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-458">[456]</a></sup> Djokovic leads on hard courts 20–7 while Nadal leads on clay 20–8, and they are tied on grass 2–2.<sup id="cite_ref-FEDEX_ATP_HEAD_2_HEADs_459-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-FEDEX_ATP_HEAD_2_HEADs-459">[457]</a></sup>

Djokovic is the only player to have beaten Nadal in all four majors. He is also the player with the most victories over Nadal on clay, beating him twice at the French Open and all three claycourt Masters events, notably in [2013 Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Monte-Carlo_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2018 Monte-Carlo Masters – Singles") where he ended Nadal's run of 8 consecutive titles. Djokovic has two streaks of seven victories against Nadal, in 2011–2012 and 2015–2016. The two contested in the longest major finals match ever played at the [2012 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2012 Australian Open – Men's singles") where Djokovic won in five sets lasting 5 hours and 53 minutes.<sup id="cite_ref-460" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-460">[458]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-461" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-461">[459]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-462" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-462">[460]</a></sup> Other classics they played include the [2009 Madrid Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Mutua_Madrile%C3%B1a_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2009 Mutua Madrileña Madrid Open – Men's singles") semifinal,<sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-463">[461]</a></sup> [2011 Miami Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Sony_Ericsson_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2011 Sony Ericsson Open – Men's singles") final,<sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-464">[462]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-465" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-465">[463]</a></sup> the [2013 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2013 French Open – Men's singles") semifinal,<sup id="cite_ref-466" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-466">[464]</a></sup> [2018 Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles") semifinal,<sup id="cite_ref-467" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-467">[465]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-468" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-468">[466]</a></sup> and the [2021 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2021 French Open – Men's singles") semifinal.<sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-469">[467]</a></sup>

### Roger Federer

Main article: [Djokovic–Federer rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Djokovic%E2%80%93Federer_rivalry "Djokovic–Federer rivalry")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Novak_Djokovic_and_Roger_Federer_at_USO_2011_%28cropped%29.jpg/300px-Novak_Djokovic_and_Roger_Federer_at_USO_2011_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Novak_Djokovic_and_Roger_Federer_at_USO_2011_(cropped).jpg)

Djokovic and Federer after their semifinal match at the [2011 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2011 US Open – Men's singles")

Djokovic and Roger Federer rivalry is considered to be one of the greatest rivalries in tennis history. They faced each other 50 times, with Djokovic leading 27–23, including 13–6 in finals (not including a [2014 walkover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_ATP_World_Tour_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles "2014 ATP World Tour Finals – Singles") in favour of Djokovic). Djokovic leads on hard courts 20–18 as well as on grass 3–1 and they are split 4–4 on clay.<sup id="cite_ref-470" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-470">[468]</a></sup>

Djokovic is the player with the most victories over Federer and the only player to beat Federer multiple times at his most successful major tournaments, four times at the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Open "Australian Open"), three times at the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Open_(tennis) "US Open (tennis)"), three times at the [Year-end Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Finals "ATP Finals") and most notably, three times at the final of [Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wimbledon_Championships "Wimbledon Championships"). Their most recent final was at the [2019 Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2019 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles") where Djokovic won in five sets in what became the longest final in [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wimbledon_Championships "Wimbledon Championships") history.<sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-471">[469]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-472" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-472">[470]</a></sup> Other notable matches they contested are the [2014 Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final "2014 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles final") and [2015 Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final "2015 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles final") finals, along with semifinals at the [2010 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2010 US Open – Men's singles"), [2011 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2011 US Open – Men's singles"), [2011 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2011 French Open – Men's singles"), and [2018 Paris Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Rolex_Paris_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2018 Rolex Paris Masters – Singles").<sup id="cite_ref-Mitchell_161-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Mitchell-161">[159]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-473" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-473">[471]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-474" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-474">[472]</a></sup>

### Andy Murray

Main article: [Djokovic–Murray rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Djokovic%E2%80%93Murray_rivalry "Djokovic–Murray rivalry")

Djokovic and [Andy Murray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray "Andy Murray") have met 36 times, with Djokovic leading 25–11.<sup id="cite_ref-475" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-475">[473]</a></sup> Djokovic leads on hard courts 20–8 and 5–1 on clay, while Murray has won the two matches played on grass. Djokovic and Murray are one of two pairs to have met in each of the four major finals (other pair being Djokovic and Nadal). The two are almost exactly the same age, with Murray being a week older than Djokovic, so they progressed through the ranks of the junior circuit together, and Murray was the winner of the first match they ever played as teenagers at _Les [Petits As](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petits_As "Petits As")_ in 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-suu_52-4" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-suu-52">[50]</a></sup> They were the [2015](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_ATP_World_Tour "2015 ATP World Tour") and [2016](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_ATP_World_Tour "2016 ATP World Tour") year-end top two players in the world, with the battle for the 2016 year-end No. 1 only being decided in the final of the [World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_ATP_World_Tour_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles "2016 ATP World Tour Finals – Singles"), which was won by Murray in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-476">[474]</a></sup>

One of their most notable matches was a three-set thriller at the final of the [2012 Shanghai Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters "2012 Shanghai Rolex Masters"), in which Djokovic saved five championship points to win his first Shanghai Masters title and end Murray's 12–0 winning streak at the event.<sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-477">[475]</a></sup> Tennis pundits have classified many more of their matches as instant classics, such as the [2011 Italian Open semifinals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2011 Italian Open – Men's singles"), the [2012 Australian Open semifinal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2012 Australian Open – Men's singles"), [2012 US Open final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final "2012 US Open – Men's singles final"), the [2015 semifinal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2015 French Open – Men's singles") and [2016 final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2016 French Open – Men's singles") at the French Open, and the [2017 Qatar Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Qatar_ExxonMobil_Open_%E2%80%93_Singles "2017 Qatar ExxonMobil Open – Singles") final.<sup id="cite_ref-478" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-478">[476]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-479" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-479">[477]</a></sup>

### Stan Wawrinka

Djokovic and [Stan Wawrinka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka "Stan Wawrinka") have met 27 times with Djokovic leading 21–6. Although this rivalry is lopsided in favor of Djokovic, the two have contested numerous close matches, including four five-setters at the majors.<sup id="cite_ref-480" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-480">[478]</a></sup> Wawrinka and Djokovic have met in three consecutive Australian Opens – with each match going to five sets – and a five-setter in the US Open. In the [2013 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2013 Australian Open – Men's singles") fourth round, Djokovic won 12–10 in a fifth set, with the match being considered one of the best ever played;<sup id="cite_ref-481" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-481">[479]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:12_198-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:12-198">[196]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-482" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-482">[480]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:10_199-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:10-199">[197]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:13_202-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:13-202">[200]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:11_200-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:11-200">[198]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-483" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-483">[481]</a></sup> at the [2013 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2013 US Open – Men's singles") semifinals Djokovic won 6–4 in the fifth set; at the [2014 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2014 Australian Open – Men's singles") quarterfinals, Wawrinka won 9–7 in the fifth.<sup id="cite_ref-Stanimal_73-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Stanimal-73">[71]</a></sup> Wawrinka's win broke Djokovic's run of 14 consecutive major semifinals, and ended a 28-match winning streak; and Wawrinka went on to win his first major title at the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-484" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-484">[482]</a></sup> Djokovic got revenge the next year at the [2015 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2015 Australian Open – Men's singles"), winning 6–0 in the fifth set.<sup id="cite_ref-485" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-485">[483]</a></sup>

At the [2015 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2015 French Open – Men's singles") final, Wawrinka defeated Djokovic in four sets to claim his second major title. Later that year, Djokovic beat Wawrinka at the [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Western_%26_Southern_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2015 Western & Southern Open – Men's singles") and [Paris Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_BNP_Paribas_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2015 BNP Paribas Masters – Singles").<sup id="cite_ref-wawrinka_486-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-wawrinka-486">[484]</a></sup> At the [2016 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2016 US Open – Men's singles"), Wawrinka beat Djokovic in a major final for a second time.<sup id="cite_ref-487" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-487">[485]</a></sup>

Despite Djokovic's 21–6 overall record against Wawrinka, Wawrinka leads Djokovic 3–2 in [ATP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_of_Tennis_Professionals "Association of Tennis Professionals") finals, two of which in major finals.<sup id="cite_ref-488" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-488">[486]</a></sup> During Djokovic's run of 13 major finals from the 2014 Wimbledon Championships through the 2020 Australian Open, his only two losses were to Wawrinka. Contrary to most high-profile rivalries, the pair have also played doubles together.<sup id="cite_ref-489" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-489">[487]</a></sup>

### Juan Martín del Potro

Djokovic and [Juan Martín del Potro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Mart%C3%ADn_del_Potro "Juan Martín del Potro") met 20 times, with Djokovic leading 16–4.<sup id="cite_ref-490" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-490">[488]</a></sup> Djokovic won their first four meetings, before back-to-back victories for del Potro at the 2011 Davis Cup and their Bronze medal match at the [2012 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's singles") in straight sets. Djokovic won the next four matches before he lost to del Potro at the [2013 Indian Wells Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2013 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles"), where the Argentine made his second career Masters final. Djokovic got the upper hand on the rivalry once again by winning two of the most important matches between them to date; an epic five-setter at the [2013 Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2013 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles") semifinals (which was the longest Wimbledon semifinal at the time),<sup id="cite_ref-491" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-491">[489]</a></sup> and a thrilling three-setter at the [2013 Shanghai Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2013 Shanghai Rolex Masters – Singles") final. Del Potro upset Djokovic in the first round at the [2016 Rio Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's singles") in [Rio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro "Rio de Janeiro") en route to the final. In 2018, Djokovic defeated del Potro in three close sets in the final of the [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 US Open – Men's singles"), which was the first Grand Slam final for del Potro since his [2009 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2009 US Open – Men's singles") victory. They played their last match at the [2019 Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2019 Italian Open – Men's singles") quarterfinal which Djokovic won in a dramatic three-setter after saving two match points.

### Jo-Wilfried Tsonga

Djokovic and [Jo-Wilfried Tsonga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jo-Wilfried_Tsonga "Jo-Wilfried Tsonga") met 23 times, with Djokovic leading 17–6.<sup id="cite_ref-vstsonga_492-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-vstsonga-492">[490]</a></sup> Their first meeting was in the final of the [2008 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Australian_Open "2008 Australian Open"), which Djokovic won in four sets to win his first major singles title.<sup id="cite_ref-vstsonga_492-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-vstsonga-492">[490]</a></sup> Tsonga got revenge in their next meeting at the majors, the [2010 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Australian_Open "2010 Australian Open") quarterfinals, winning in five sets after Djokovic fell ill during the match.<sup id="cite_ref-493" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-493">[491]</a></sup> Djokovic then won their next match at the [2011 Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Wimbledon_Championships "2011 Wimbledon Championships") semifinals to advance to his first final there, claiming the world No. 1 ranking for the first time in the process.<sup id="cite_ref-494" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-494">[492]</a></sup> They met again in the quarterfinals of the 2012 French Open, which Djokovic won in five sets after over four hours.<sup id="cite_ref-495" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-495">[493]</a></sup> They then played a further three matches in 2012, in the quarterfinals of the [Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics "Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics"), the final of the [China Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_China_Open_(tennis) "2012 China Open (tennis)"), and in the round robin stage of the [ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_ATP_World_Tour_Finals "2012 ATP World Tour Finals"), with Djokovic winning all of them in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-vstsonga_492-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-vstsonga-492">[490]</a></sup> Their final major meeting was in the second round of the [2019 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Australian_Open "2019 Australian Open"), which Djokovic won in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-vstsonga_492-3" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-vstsonga-492">[490]</a></sup>

### Dominic Thiem
