Djokovic and [Dominic Thiem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominic_Thiem "Dominic Thiem") have met 12 times, with Djokovic leading 7–5.<sup id="cite_ref-VSThiem_496-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-VSThiem-496">[494]</a></sup> They have met four times at the majors, splitting them evenly 2–2, and three times at the ATP finals, with Thiem leading 2–1.<sup id="cite_ref-VSThiem_496-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-VSThiem-496">[494]</a></sup> The two have contested numerous close matches, with each of their last four meetings ending with a deciding set, including two five-setters at the majors.<sup id="cite_ref-VSThiem_496-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-VSThiem-496">[494]</a></sup> This streak started with a grueling four-hour, five-set epic stretched across two days in the semifinals of the 2019 French Open, which Thiem won to end Djokovic's quest for a second "Nole Slam".<sup id="cite_ref-Thiem_306-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Thiem-306">[304]</a></sup> They then played in the round robin stage of the 2019 ATP Finals, which Thiem won in a deciding set tiebreaker. This was followed by the 2020 Australian Open final, which Djokovic won in five sets, while their last match, the semifinals of the 2020 ATP Finals, was won by Thiem in three sets.<sup id="cite_ref-VSThiem_496-3" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-VSThiem-496">[494]</a></sup>

### Daniil Medvedev

Djokovic and [Daniil Medvedev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniil_Medvedev "Daniil Medvedev") have met 15 times, with Djokovic leading 10–5.<sup id="cite_ref-vsmedvedev_497-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-vsmedvedev-497">[495]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-498" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-498">[496]</a></sup> They have contested 4 Grand Slam matches, with Djokovic leading 3–1. Their first Grand Slam match came at the [2019 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2019 Australian Open – Men's singles") 4th round, which Djokovic won in 4 sets. Their next 3 encounters at the Majors came in finals, with Djokovic winning the [2021 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2021 Australian Open – Men's singles") and the [2023 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2023 US Open – Men's singles") finals, and Medvedev winning his first major title at the [2021 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2021 US Open – Men's singles") against Djokovic in the final, also ending Djokovic's quest for a calendar-year Grand Slam.<sup id="cite_ref-499" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-499">[497]</a></sup> Medvedev replaced Djokovic as the world No. 1 player when he rose to the top ranking for the first time in February 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-500" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-500">[498]</a></sup> All 3 Grand Slam finals between Djokovic and Medvedev were straight set wins. The second set of the 2023 US Open, which Djokovic eventually won in a tiebreaker after a grueling 104-minute battle, was one of the longest sets in US Open history.<sup id="cite_ref-501" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-501">[499]</a></sup>

### Stefanos Tsitsipas

Djokovic and [Stefanos Tsitsipas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stefanos_Tsitsipas "Stefanos Tsitsipas") have met 13 times, with Djokovic leading 11–2.<sup id="cite_ref-vstsitsipas_502-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-vstsitsipas-502">[500]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-503" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-503">[501]</a></sup> Their first meeting took place in the third round of the [2018 Rogers Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Rogers_Cup_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2018 Rogers Cup – Men's singles"), with the then 19-year-old Tsitsipas, ranked No. 27, pulling an upset over Djokovic in three sets.<sup id="cite_ref-504" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-504">[502]</a></sup> Djokovic avenged this loss by beating Tsitsipas in the [2019 Madrid Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Mutua_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2019 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's singles"), but Tstisipas then won their next match in the quarterfinals of the [2019 Shanghai Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Rolex_Shanghai_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2019 Rolex Shanghai Masters – Singles") to bring their head-to-head to 2–1 in his favor.<sup id="cite_ref-vstsitsipas_502-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-vstsitsipas-502">[500]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-505" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-505">[503]</a></sup> Djokovic then won all of their next ten matches, among them are the [2020 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2020 French Open – Men's singles") semifinal; the [2021 Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2021 Italian Open – Men's singles") quarterfinal spread over two days;<sup id="cite_ref-506" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-506">[504]</a></sup> the [2021 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2021 French Open – Men's singles") final which saw Djokovic coming back from 2 sets to 0 down to win his second French Open title; the [2022 Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 Italian Open – Men's singles") final; and the [2023 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2023 Australian Open – Men's singles") final, where the two were competing for the world No. 1 ranking.<sup id="cite_ref-vstsitsipas_502-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-vstsitsipas-502">[500]</a></sup>

### Carlos Alcaraz

Djokovic and [Carlos Alcaraz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Alcaraz "Carlos Alcaraz") have met five times, with Djokovic leading 3–2. Both have won once at a Grand Slam tournament and once at a Masters tournament, and Djokovic defeated Alcaraz in the semifinals of [2023 ATP Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_ATP_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles "2023 ATP Finals – Singles").<sup id="cite_ref-507" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-507">[505]</a></sup>

Their first meeting was at the [2022 Madrid Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Mutua_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's singles") semifinals, in which Alcaraz prevailed in a deciding set tiebreaker. Their next meeting would not be until the [2023 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2023 French Open – Men's singles") semifinals, in which Djokovic won in four sets. The match was competitive until Alcaraz faltered due to cramps from mental pressure and physical intensity.<sup id="cite_ref-508" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-508">[506]</a></sup> They would meet again soon after in the [2023 Wimbledon final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final "2023 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles final"), in which Alcaraz would defeat Djokovic in a five-setter that lasted 4 hours and 42 minutes, ending his hopes for a calendar Grand Slam and his record 45-match [Centre Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centre_Court "Centre Court") win streak.<sup id="cite_ref-509" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-509">[507]</a></sup> They would meet soon again in another epic at the [2023 Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Western_%26_Southern_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2023 Western & Southern Open – Men's singles") final, with Djokovic prevailing in three tightly contested sets after saving a match point. The match was the longest best-of-three-sets [ATP Tour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Tour "ATP Tour") final and the longest match in the tournament's history, at 3 hours and 49 minutes, and was immediately praised as one of the best matches ever.<sup id="cite_ref-:82_433-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:82-433">[431]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:9_434-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:9-434">[432]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-510" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-510">[508]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-511" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-511">[509]</a></sup> Djokovic won despite being a set down and down a break in the second set, along with saving a championship point in the second-set tiebreaker.<sup id="cite_ref-512" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-512">[510]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-513" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-513">[511]</a></sup>

## Legacy

> I believe that numbers are numbers and statistics are statistics and, in that sense, I think he \[Djokovic\] has better numbers than mine and that is indisputable. It is not beneath me nor do I have an ego big enough to try and disguise a reality that is not. This is the truth. The rest are tastes, inspiration, sensations that one player or the other may transmit to you, that you may like one or the other more. I think that with respect to titles, Djokovic is the best in history and there is nothing to discuss in that.

— [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal"), on Djokovic's legacy shortly after he won the 2023 US Open for his 24th Grand Slam.<sup id="cite_ref-514" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-514">[512]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-515" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-515">[513]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-516" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-516">[514]</a></sup>

Djokovic is regarded by many observers, tennis players and coaches as the greatest tennis player of all time, primarily for his achievements across all top-level tournaments of the men's professional tour in addition to his time spent with the [world No. 1 ranking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_rankings#ATP_No._1_ranked_singles_players "ATP rankings"). Many media outlets, including [Forbes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes "Forbes"), [Reuters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reuters "Reuters"), [Sports Illustrated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_Illustrated "Sports Illustrated"), [ESPN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN "ESPN"), [Marca](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marca_(newspaper) "Marca (newspaper)"), Tennis World USA, [Australian Broadcasting Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Broadcasting_Corporation "Australian Broadcasting Corporation"), and [Sporting News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sporting_News "The Sporting News") have named Djokovic the greatest male tennis player in history.<sup id="cite_ref-517" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-517">[515]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-518" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-518">[516]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-519" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-519">[517]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-520" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-520">[518]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-521" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-521">[519]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-522" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-522">[520]</a></sup>

Djokovic has won a record 71 [Big Titles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ATP_Tour_top-level_tournament_singles_champions "List of ATP Tour top-level tournament singles champions"), including an all-time record of 24 [Grand Slam titles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Grand_Slam_men%27s_singles_champions "List of Grand Slam men's singles champions"), and holds the most [weeks at No. 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ATP_number_1_ranked_singles_tennis_players "List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players"), the most wins over top 5 and top 10-ranked players, has won all major and [Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_Masters_Series_singles_records_and_statistics "Tennis Masters Series singles records and statistics") events and the [year-end championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Finals "ATP Finals") at least twice (which has not been done by another player once) and has a winning head-to-head record over his greatest rivals in one of the strongest eras of tennis.<sup id="cite_ref-523" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-523">[521]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Metro_524-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Metro-524">[522]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Cash_525-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Cash-525">[523]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto_526-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-529">[527]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-530" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-530">[528]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-531" class="reference"><a Djokovic the "greatest tennis player in history" after winning his first major title at the [2021 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2021 US Open – Men's Krajicek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Krajicek "Richard Krajicek") and _[The Roar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Roar_(website) "The Roar (website)")_, sports opinion website, said that I don't know anybody who's ever played tennis like this. Since I know this sport I've never seen somebody playing at this level."<sup id="cite_ref-539" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-539">[537]</a></sup> In 2017, Nadal stated that "at a technical level, when Djokovic has been at the top of his game, I have to say that I’ve been up against an invincible player."<sup id="cite_ref-540" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-540">[538]</a></sup> In 2023, former world No. 7 [Mardy Fish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mardy_Fish "Mardy Fish") also declared that Djokovic in 2011 was "the best player of all time".<sup id="cite_ref-541" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-541">[539]</a></sup> In 2023, [Boris Becker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boris_Becker "Boris Becker") compared Djokovic to [Lionel Messi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lionel_Messi "Lionel Messi"), [Tom Brady](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Brady "Tom Brady") and [LeBron James](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LeBron_James "LeBron James") in their respective sports, saying that "For me, he is the lion king".<sup id="cite_ref-542" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-542">[540]</a></sup>

Tennis coach [Nick Bollettieri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nick_Bollettieri "Nick Bollettieri") praised Djokovic as the "most complete player ever",<sup id="cite_ref-543" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-543">[541]</a></sup> and the "most perfect player of all time":<sup id="cite_ref-544" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-544">[542]</a></sup>

> When you look at match players in the history of tennis, I don't believe that anybody can equal everything on the court that Djokovic does. I don't think you can find a weakness in his game. His movement, personality, his return of serve, his serve, excellent touch, not hesitant in coming to the net, great serve. Overall, almost every player has a downfall; to me, he doesn't have one. He's perhaps the best put-together player that I've seen over 60 years.<sup id="cite_ref-545" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-545">[543]</a></sup>

[Andre Agassi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andre_Agassi "Andre Agassi"), stated in an interview in 2019 with the Times of India that:

The single level, for whatever my tennis IQ is worth, is an unmistakable standard to which everybody will strive to be.<sup id="cite_ref-546" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-546">[544]</a></sup>

[Pete Sampras](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pete_Sampras "Pete Sampras"), who at the time of his retirement in 2003 was considered by some to be the greatest male tennis player of all time, stated after Djokovic earned a record-breaking seventh year-end No. 1 finish in 2021:

He did it at a time where he dominated two of the greats, in Roger and Rafa, and he handled the next generation of players very well – all at the same time. I do think what Novak's done over the past 10 years, winning the majors, being consistent, finishing number one for seven years, to me it's a clear sign that he is the greatest of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-sampras_528-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-sampras-528">[526]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-547" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-547">[545]</a></sup>

## Player profile

### Playing style

Djokovic is an [aggressive baseline player](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_strategy#Offensive_baseliner "Tennis strategy").<sup id="cite_ref-tennisworld1_555-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-tennisworld1-555">[553]</a></sup> His groundstrokes from both wings are consistent, deep, and penetrating. His backhand is widely regarded as the greatest two-handed backhand of all time, due to its effectiveness on both sides of the court and its accuracy.<sup id="cite_ref-556" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-556">[554]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-557" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-557">[555]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-558" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-558">[556]</a></sup> His best shot is his backhand down the line, with great pace and precision. He excels at returning serve in particular, and regularly ranks among the tour leaders in return points, return games, and break points won. His forehand is deemed to be underrated, yet one of the best, due to its versatility.<sup id="cite_ref-559" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-559">[557]</a></sup> After great technical difficulties during the 2009 season (coinciding with his switch to the Head racket series), his [serve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serve_(tennis) "Serve (tennis)") is one of his major weapons again, winning him many free points; his first serve is typically hit flat, while he prefers to slice and kick his second serves wide.<sup id="cite_ref-tennisworld1_555-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-tennisworld1-555">[553]</a></sup> He has also led the [ATP Tour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Tour "ATP Tour") in their career "Under Pressure Rating" statistic, in part because of his prowess at winning deciding sets.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Novak_Djokovic_Eastbourne_2017_%28cropped%29.jpg/200px-Novak_Djokovic_Eastbourne_2017_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Novak_Djokovic_Eastbourne_2017_(cropped).jpg)

Djokovic serving at the [Eastbourne International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Aegon_International_Eastbourne_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2017 Aegon International Eastbourne – Men's singles"). Djokovic plays with a [Head](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_(company) "Head (company)") racquet and wears [Lacoste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lacoste "Lacoste") apparel and [Asics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asics "Asics") shoes.

Djokovic has been described as one of the fittest and most complete athletes in sports history, with high agility, court coverage and mobility, which allows him to hit winners from seemingly indefensible positions.<sup id="cite_ref-560" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-560">[558]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-561" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-561">[559]</a></sup> Because of this, coupled with flexibility and length, he rarely gets [aced](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ace_(tennis) "Ace (tennis)"). [Todd Martin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Todd_Martin "Todd Martin"), who coached Djokovic between 2009 and 2010, noted that:<sup id="cite_ref-562" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-562">[560]</a></sup>

> His athleticism is from another world. His return of serve is way better than any other return of serve ever and I mean way better. Nobody has gotten so many balls back and neutralized so many good serves.

Djokovic's return of serve is a big weapon for him, with which he can be both offensive and defensive. He is highly efficient off both the forehand and backhand return, often getting the return in play deep with pace, neutralizing the advantage the server usually has in a point. [Andre Agassi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andre_Agassi "Andre Agassi") described Djokovic's return of serve as "the precedent-setting standard for the return".<sup id="cite_ref-563" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-563">[561]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-564" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-564">[562]</a></sup> Occasionally, Djokovic employs a well-disguised backhand underspin [drop shot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drop_shot "Drop shot") and sliced backhand.

Djokovic commented on the modern style of play, including his own, in an interview with [Jim Courier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Courier "Jim Courier") after his semifinal win against [Andy Murray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray "Andy Murray") in the [2012 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Australian_Open "2012 Australian Open") tournament:<sup id="cite_ref-565" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-565">[563]</a></sup>

> I had a big privilege and honour to meet personally today Mr. [Laver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rod_Laver "Rod Laver"), and he is one of the biggest, and greatest players ever to play the game, thank you for staying this late, sir, thank you ... even though it would actually be better if we played a couple times serve and volley, but we don't know to play ... we are mostly around here \[points to the area near the baseline\], we are running, you know, around the baseline ...

In assessing Djokovic's 2011 season, [Jimmy Connors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Connors "Jimmy Connors") said that Djokovic gives his opponents problems by playing "a little bit old-school, taking the ball earlier, catching the ball on the rise, (and) driving the ball flat." Connors adds that a lot of the topspin that Djokovic's opponents drive at him comes right into his zone, thus his ability to turn defense into offense well.<sup id="cite_ref-566" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-566">[564]</a></sup>

### Equipment

Entering the pro circuit, Djokovic used the [Head](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_(company) "Head (company)") Liquidmetal Radical, but changed sponsors to [Wilson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilson_Sporting_Goods "Wilson Sporting Goods") in 2005. He could not find a Wilson racquet he liked, so Wilson agreed to make him a custom racquet to match his previous one with Head.<sup id="cite_ref-567" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-567">[565]</a></sup> After the 2008 season, Djokovic re-signed with Head, and debuted a new paint job of the Head YouTek Speed Pro at the 2009 [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Open "Australian Open"). He then switched to the Head YouTek IG Speed (18x20) paint job in 2011, and in 2013, he again updated his paint job to the Head Graphene Speed Pro, which included an extensive promotional campaign.<sup id="cite_ref-568" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-568">[566]</a></sup> Djokovic uses a hybrid of Head Natural Gut (gauge 16) in the mains and Luxilon Big Banger ALU Power Rough (gauge 16L) in the crosses. He also uses Head Synthetic Leather Grip as a replacement grip.<sup id="cite_ref-569" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-569">[567]</a></sup> In 2012, Djokovic appeared in a television commercial with [Maria Sharapova](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maria_Sharapova "Maria Sharapova") promoting the use of Head rackets for many techniques such as golf and ten-pin bowling.<sup id="cite_ref-570" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-570">[568]</a></sup>

### Coaching and personal team

See also: [Novak Djokovic coaches](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic_coaches "Novak Djokovic coaches")

Djokovic had several coaches, trainers, and advisors throughout his life, and each of them has helped Djokovic become and stay a champion. He has learned from all them and picked up at least something good from everyone. Djokovic's most important coaches when he was growing up were Jelena Genčić, who he has called his “tennis mother”, and Nikola Pilić, the “tennis father”, both of which were major influences on his young life.<sup id="cite_ref-reuters_35-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-reuters-35">[33]</a></sup> Genčić worked with Djokovic for six years between 1993 and 1999, from ages six to 12, mainly at Belgrade's [Teniski Klub Partizan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teniski_Klub_Partizan "Teniski Klub Partizan"), while Pilić worked with him between 1999 and 2003, coaching him in his academy in Munich.<sup id="cite_ref-spiegel_30-6" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-spiegel-30">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-making1_32-3" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-making1-32">[30]</a></sup>

In the period 2004 and 2005, Djokovic was coached by [Dejan Petrović](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dejan_Petrovi%C4%87 "Dejan Petrović").<sup id="cite_ref-571" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-571">[569]</a></sup> Under the mentoring of Petrović, Djokovic went from being ranked outside the top 300 to breaking into the top 100 in less than a year.<sup id="cite_ref-572" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-572">[570]</a></sup> From fall 2005 until June 2006, he was coached by [Riccardo Piatti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riccardo_Piatti "Riccardo Piatti"), who divided his time between the 18-year-old and [Ivan Ljubičić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivan_Ljubi%C4%8Di%C4%87 "Ivan Ljubičić"). Player and coach reportedly parted ways over the latter's refusal to work full-time with Djokovic.<sup id="cite_ref-timeline_65-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-timeline-65">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-573" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-573">[571]</a></sup>

From June 2006 until May 2017, Djokovic was coached by former professional Slovakian tennis player [Marián Vajda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mari%C3%A1n_Vajda "Marián Vajda"). They met for the first time during that year's French Open, after which Vajda was hired to be the 19-year-old's coach. On occasion Djokovic employed additional coaches on a part-time basis: in 2007, during the spring hardcourt season, he worked with Australian doubles ace [Mark Woodforde](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Woodforde "Mark Woodforde") with specific emphasis on volleys and net play while from August 2009 until April 2010 American [Todd Martin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Todd_Martin "Todd Martin") joined the coaching team, a period marked by his ill-fated attempt to change Djokovic's serve motion.<sup id="cite_ref-574" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-574">[572]</a></sup> From early 2007 until 2017, Djokovic worked with physiotherapist Miljan Amanović, who had previously worked with football team [Red Star Belgrade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KK_Crvena_zvezda "KK Crvena zvezda"), and NBA players, such as [Vladimir Radmanović](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Radmanovi%C4%87 "Vladimir Radmanović").<sup id="cite_ref-timeline_65-3" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-timeline-65">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-575" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-575">[573]</a></sup>

From the fall of 2006, Djokovic had an Israeli fitness coach, Ronen Bega, but the two parted ways during the spring of 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-576" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-576">[574]</a></sup> Djokovic decided to make a change after identifying his conditioning as a weakness in his game following continual losses to Nadal.<sup id="cite_ref-577" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-577">[575]</a></sup> In April 2009, ahead of the [Rome Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2009 Italian Open – Men's singles"), Djokovic hired Austrian Gebhard Phil-Gritsch (formerly worked with [Thomas Muster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Muster "Thomas Muster")) to join the team in fitness coach capacity.<sup id="cite_ref-578" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-578">[576]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-579" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-579">[577]</a></sup>

In 2008, Djokovic hired Italian agent Edoardo Artaldi and his management team, which includes his wife, Elena Capellaro, to oversee the huge operation that runs around him. They met when Djokovic signed a contract with the Italian clothing brand Sergio Tacchini, where Artaldi was working at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-chief_580-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-chief-580">[578]</a></sup> Despite taking a lead role as an agent and business manager, Artaldi has acted like a father figure in Djokovic's camp. During an interview with Italian outlet SBS in 2019, Artaldi explained that, together with his wife, they have tried to “create the atmosphere” that Djokovic needed while on tour because he missed his family while traveling.<sup id="cite_ref-chief_580-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-chief-580">[578]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Artaldi_581-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Artaldi-581">[579]</a></sup> Djokovic's relationship with Artaldi has had its challenging moments, as he screamed at Artaldi and brother [Marko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marko_Djokovic "Marko Djokovic") to leave his box during the final of the [2023 Adelaide Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Adelaide_International_1_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2023 Adelaide International 1 – Men's singles").<sup id="cite_ref-chief_580-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-chief-580">[578]</a></sup>

In July 2010, before the Davis Cup clash away at Croatia, Djokovic made another addition to his team – Igor Četojević, a Serbian nutritionist and proponent of [traditional medicine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traditional_medicine "Traditional medicine") living in Cyprus,<sup id="cite_ref-čovek_582-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-%C4%8Dovek-582">[580]</a></sup> who influenced Djokovic's diet.<sup id="cite_ref-Refrigerator_583-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Refrigerator-583">[581]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-584" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-584">[582]</a></sup> A [gluten-free diet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gluten-free_diet "Gluten-free diet") appeared to have worked as Djokovic began feeling stronger, quicker, and much more fit.<sup id="cite_ref-Refrigerator_583-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Refrigerator-583">[581]</a></sup> After Djokovic's Wimbledon win in July 2011, Četojević left the team.<sup id="cite_ref-585" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-585">[583]</a></sup>

After retiring from professional tennis in August 2011, Serbian player [Dušan Vemić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Du%C5%A1an_Vemi%C4%87 "Dušan Vemić") joined Djokovic's team as the assistant coach and hitting partner for Novak. The collaboration ended before the [2013 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2013 US Open – Men's singles").<sup id="cite_ref-586" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-586">[584]</a></sup> Likewise, Djokovic's childhood friend and former junior doubles partner [Bojan Božović](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bojan_Bo%C5%BEovi%C4%87_(tennis) "Bojan Božović (tennis)") also briefly served as a hitting partner for Novak in late 2014, shortly after Božović had opened his academy.<sup id="cite_ref-Raonic_57-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Raonic-57">[55]</a></sup> Due to Božović's height and strong serve, Djokovic specifically practiced his returns with him, most notably for the [2014 Paris Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_BNP_Paribas_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2014 BNP Paribas Masters – Singles") final against [Milos Raonic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milos_Raonic "Milos Raonic"), a player with a powerful serve.<sup id="cite_ref-Raonic_57-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Raonic-57">[55]</a></sup>

Six-time major champion and former world No. 1 [Boris Becker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boris_Becker "Boris Becker"), who had mostly worked as a television pundit for [BBC Sport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_Sport "BBC Sport") and [Sky Sports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sky_Sports "Sky Sports") since retiring from playing in 1999, was announced as Djokovic's new head coach in December 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-587" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-587">[585]</a></sup> According to Djokovic, the Becker appointment was done with input from the player's existing head coach Marián Vajda who reportedly wanted to spend more time with his family and was looking to have his coaching workload somewhat reduced.<sup id="cite_ref-588" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-588">[586]</a></sup> For Becker, in addition to working alongside Vajda, the job entailed special emphasis on Grand Slam tournaments as Djokovic felt he missed out on winning a couple of majors over the previous two seasons due to a lack of mental edge in the final stages of those tournaments.<sup id="cite_ref-589" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-589">[587]</a></sup> Becker's first tournament coaching Djokovic was the [2014 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2014 Australian Open – Men's singles").

On 5 May 2017, Djokovic confirmed that he had come to a mutual agreement to terminate his coaching relationship with Vajda, as well as Phil-Gritsch and Amanović. In a statement on his website, Djokovic cited the reasons for the personnel shakeup: "Novak and the team members decided to part ways after a detailed analysis of the game, achieved results in the previous period, and also after discussing private plans of each team member. Despite the fantastic cooperation so far, Djokovic felt he needed to make a change, and to introduce new energy in order to raise his level of play."<sup id="cite_ref-590" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-590">[588]</a></sup>

Djokovic reunited with Marián Vajda in April 2018 for the Monte-Carlo Masters.<sup id="cite_ref-591" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-591">[589]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-592" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-592">[590]</a></sup> On 30 June 2019, Djokovic confirmed that he also added former world No. 2 and Wimbledon champion [Goran Ivanišević](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goran_Ivani%C5%A1evi%C4%87 "Goran Ivanišević") to his coaching team.<sup id="cite_ref-593" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-593">[591]</a></sup>

In late 2021, Djokovic decided to play fewer tournaments due to both his age and his desire to mainly focus his energy on the Grand Slam championships, and as such, he decided to be with a smaller team that had only one coach, and he chose Ivanišević due to Vajda's reluctance to coach just one player only at the majors.<sup id="cite_ref-Vajda_594-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Vajda-594">[592]</a></sup> Djokovic and Vajda thus parted ways for a second time in December 2021, but it was only made public in March 2022,<sup id="cite_ref-Vajda_594-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Vajda-594">[592]</a></sup> when both announced that Vajda would no longer coach Djokovic and that it was an amicable and mutual decision. Vajda promised to remain his 'biggest support' on and off the court. Djokovic said on Twitter "What a journey Marian. 15 years!"<sup id="cite_ref-595" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-595">[593]</a></sup> In addition to Ivanišević as his new coach, Djokovic also added fitness trainer Marco Panichi and hitting partner [Carlos Gómez-Herrera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_G%C3%B3mez-Herrera "Carlos Gómez-Herrera"), a retired tennis player with whom he had been friends for around 15 years, while also keeping physiotherapist Miljan Amanović.<sup id="cite_ref-Artaldi_581-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Artaldi-581">[579]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-596" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-596">[594]</a></sup>

In late 2023, Djokovic decided to end his professional long-term association with Edoardo Artaldi's management team, who had been with him since 2008, stating that “I’m now at a stage where I'm entering a new chapter about the off-court approach”.<sup id="cite_ref-Artaldi_581-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Artaldi-581">[579]</a></sup> In a heartfelt message of gratitude for them, Djokovic stated: "My appreciation and love for you two personally goes beyond any professional relationship. What you did for me and my family privately and the amount of care and empathy you had all these years, especially towards my wife and kids is something very special for me and I will never forget that".<sup id="cite_ref-597" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-597">[595]</a></sup>

## Off the court

### Philanthropy

Kindergarten in [Jalovik](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jalovik "Jalovik") village built by the Novak Djokovic Foundation<sup id="cite_ref-598" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-598">[596]</a></sup>

In 2007, Djokovic founded the Novak Djokovic Foundation.<sup id="cite_ref-599" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-599">[597]</a></sup> The organization's mission is to help children from disadvantaged communities grow up and develop in stimulating and safe environments.<sup id="cite_ref-600" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-600">[598]</a></sup> The foundation partnered with the [World Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Bank "World Bank") in August 2015 to promote early childhood education in Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-601" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-601">[599]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-602" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-602">[600]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-603" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-603">[601]</a></sup> His foundation has built 50 schools as of April 2022 and are building their 51st, and supported more than 20,800 children and over a thousand families.<sup id="cite_ref-604" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-604">[602]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-halfagoal_605-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-halfagoal-605">[603]</a></sup>

Djokovic participated in charity matches to raise funds for the reconstruction of the [Avala Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avala_Tower "Avala Tower"), as well as to aid victims of the [2010 Haiti earthquake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Haiti_earthquake "2010 Haiti earthquake") and [2010–11 Queensland floods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_Queensland_floods "2010–11 Queensland floods").<sup id="cite_ref-606" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-606">[604]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-607" class="reference"><a
