### Sponsorships and business ventures

Djokovic endorses Serbian telecommunications company [Telekom Srbija](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telekom_Srbija "Telekom Srbija") and German nutritional supplement brand FitLine.<sup id="cite_ref-617" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-617">[615]</a></sup>

On turning professional in 2003, Djokovic began wearing [Adidas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adidas "Adidas") clothing. At the end of 2009, Djokovic signed a 10-year deal with the Italian clothing company [Sergio Tacchini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sergio_Tacchini "Sergio Tacchini") after Adidas refused to extend his clothing contract (choosing instead to sign [Andy Murray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray "Andy Murray")).<sup id="cite_ref-618" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-618">[616]</a></sup> Tacchini doesn't make shoes so Djokovic continued with Adidas as his choice of footwear. His sponsorship contract with Tacchini was incentive-heavy, and Djokovic's disproportionate success and dominance in 2011 caused the company to fall behind on bonus payments, leading to the termination of the sponsorship contract.<sup id="cite_ref-619" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-619">[617]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-620" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-620">[618]</a></sup>

From 2011, Djokovic began to wear custom Red and Blue Adidas Barricade 6.0's shoes, referring to the colours of the Serbian national flag. By April 2012, the Tacchini deal had fallen first short and then apart. At that point, he was set to join forces with [Nike, Inc.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nike,_Inc. "Nike, Inc."),<sup id="cite_ref-621" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-621">[619]</a></sup> but instead, on 23 May 2012, [Uniqlo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniqlo "Uniqlo") appointed Djokovic as its global brand ambassador. The five-year sponsorship, reportedly worth €8 million per year,<sup id="cite_ref-622" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-622">[620]</a></sup> began on 27 May 2012 in Paris' French Open tennis tournament. A year later, Djokovic's long-term footwear deal with Adidas was announced ahead of 2013 French Open.<sup id="cite_ref-623" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-623">[621]</a></sup>

In August 2011, Djokovic became the brand ambassador of Swiss watch manufacturer [Audemars Piguet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audemars_Piguet "Audemars Piguet").<sup id="cite_ref-624" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-624">[622]</a></sup> Less than a month later, Djokovic signed a sponsorship deal with German car company [Mercedes-Benz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes-Benz "Mercedes-Benz").<sup id="cite_ref-625" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-625">[623]</a></sup> In March 2012, Djokovic was announced by [Bombardier Aerospace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bombardier_Aerospace "Bombardier Aerospace") as its latest [Learjet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learjet "Learjet") brand ambassador, thus joining the likes of actor and pilot [John Travolta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Travolta "John Travolta"), architect [Frank Gehry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Gehry "Frank Gehry"), maestro [Valery Gergiev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valery_Gergiev "Valery Gergiev"), and classical pianist [Lang Lang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lang_Lang "Lang Lang").<sup id="cite_ref-626" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-626">[624]</a></sup> From January 2014 Djokovic has been endorsing French car manufacturer [Peugeot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peugeot "Peugeot").<sup id="cite_ref-627" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-627">[625]</a></sup> At the same time he entered into an endorsement deal with Japanese watch manufacturer [Seiko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seiko "Seiko"),<sup id="cite_ref-628" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-628">[626]</a></sup> having just ended his affiliation with their rivals Audemars Piguet.<sup id="cite_ref-629" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-629">[627]</a></sup> In early 2015, ahead of the [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2015 Australian Open – Men's singles"), Djokovic teamed up with Australian banking corporation [ANZ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_and_New_Zealand_Banking_Group "Australia and New Zealand Banking Group") for a social media campaign to raise money for local communities across the Asia Pacific region.<sup id="cite_ref-630" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-630">[628]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-631" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-631">[629]</a></sup> At the same time his partnership with [Jacob's Creek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob%27s_Creek_(wine) "Jacob's Creek (wine)"), an Australian wine brand owned by [Orlando Wines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orlando_Wines "Orlando Wines"), was announced in regards to the production and distribution of 'Made By' film series, a documentary style content meant to "show a side of Novak not seen before as he recounts never before told life stories from Belgrade, Serbia, celebrating what has made him the champion he is today".<sup id="cite_ref-632" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-632">[630]</a></sup>

Since 2004, the business end of Djokovic's career has been handled by Israeli managers [Amit Naor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amit_Naor "Amit Naor") (former pro tennis player turned sports agent) and Allon Khakshouri, a duo which also had [Marat Safin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marat_Safin "Marat Safin") and [Dinara Safina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dinara_Safina "Dinara Safina") as its clients. In June 2008, after the duo entered into a partnership with CAA Sports, the sports division of Hollywood talent firm [Creative Artists Agency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Creative_Artists_Agency "Creative Artists Agency"), meaning that the famous company started representing tennis players for the first time,<sup id="cite_ref-633" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-633">[631]</a></sup> Djokovic formally signed with [CAA Sports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Creative_Artists_Agency "Creative Artists Agency").<sup id="cite_ref-634" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-634">[632]</a></sup> After Djokovic's contract with CAA Sports expired during summer 2012, he decided to switch representation, announcing [IMG Worldwide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IMG_Worldwide "IMG Worldwide") as his new representatives in December 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-635" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-635">[633]</a></sup>

On 22 May 2017, Djokovic was unveiled as a brand ambassador of [Lacoste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lacoste_(company) "Lacoste (company)") after a five-year partnership with [Uniqlo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniqlo "Uniqlo").<sup id="cite_ref-636" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-636">[634]</a></sup>

During the [2021 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_US_Open_(tennis) "2021 US Open (tennis)"), some people in Djokovic's player box wore hats and shirts bearing the logo of [Raiffeisen Bank International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raiffeisen_Bank_International "Raiffeisen Bank International"), the central back of one of the two largest banking cooperatives in Austria. In April 2021, Djokovic became a brand ambassador for RBI and its subsidiaries in Central and Eastern Europe. The bank will help to support Djokovic's tennis academy in Belgrade.<sup id="cite_ref-637" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-637">[635]</a></sup> Djokovic did not wear the RBI logo, but he did wear on his shirt the logo of [UKG](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UKG "UKG"), an American [workforce management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workforce_management "Workforce management") and [human resource management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_resource_management_systems "Human resource management systems") company. People in his box wore the logo on hats as well. UKG lists Djokovic as one of their sponsored athletes.<sup id="cite_ref-638" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-638">[636]</a></sup>

#### Investments

In 2005, as Djokovic moved up the tennis rankings, he began venturing into the business world. Most of his activities in the business arena have been channeled through Family Sport, a legal entity in Serbia established and run by members of his immediate family. Registered as a [limited liability company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limited_liability_company "Limited liability company"), Family Sport initially focused on [hospitality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hospitality_industry "Hospitality industry"), specifically the restaurant business, by launching Novak Café & Restaurant, a franchise developed on the theme of Djokovic's tennis success. Over time, the company, whose day-to-day operations are mostly handled by Novak's father Srdjan and uncle Goran, expanded its activities into real estate, sports/entertainment event organization, and sports apparel distribution.<sup id="cite_ref-639" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-639">[637]</a></sup>

The company launched Novak Café & Restaurant in 2008 in the Belgrade municipality of [Novi Beograd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novi_Beograd "Novi Beograd"), the flagship location in a [franchised](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franchising "Franchising") chain of theme café-restaurants. During 2009, two more locations were added—one in [Kragujevac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kragujevac "Kragujevac") and the other in Belgrade, the city's second, in September at the neighbourhood of [Dorćol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dor%C4%87ol "Dorćol") overlooking the playing courts of [Serbia Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia_Open "Serbia Open") whose inaugural edition took place several months earlier.<sup id="cite_ref-640" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-640">[638]</a></sup> On 16 December 2011 a location in [Novi Sad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novi_Sad "Novi Sad") was opened,<sup id="cite_ref-641" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-641">[639]</a></sup> however, it operated just over three years before closing in late March 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-642" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-642">[640]</a></sup> [Banja Luka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banja_Luka "Banja Luka") in neighbouring [Bosnia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Bosnia and Herzegovina") got its Novak Café & Restaurant location on 16 October 2015 within Hotel Trešnja on Banj hill.<sup id="cite_ref-643" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-643">[641]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-644" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-644">[642]</a></sup>

In 2009, the company bought a [250-series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Tour_250 "ATP Tour 250") ATP tournament known as the [Dutch Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_Open_(tennis) "Dutch Open (tennis)") and moved it to Serbia where it was renamed the [Serbia Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia_Open "Serbia Open"). With the help of Belgrade city authorities, the tournament's inaugural edition was held in May 2009 at the city-owned "Milan Gale Muškatirović" courts, located at an attractive spot in [Dorćol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dor%C4%87ol "Dorćol") neighbourhood.<sup id="cite_ref-645" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-645">[643]</a></sup> The tournament folded in 2012 after four editions and its place in the ATP calendar got taken over by the [Düsseldorf Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D%C3%BCsseldorf_Open_(ATP_Tour) "Düsseldorf Open (ATP Tour)").

In May 2015, right after winning his fourth [Rome Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2015 Italian Open – Men's singles") title, Djokovic launched a line of nutritional food products, called _Djokolife_.<sup id="cite_ref-djokolife_646-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-djokolife-646">[644]</a></sup> On 10 April 2016, while in town for the [Monte-Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2016 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters – Singles"), Djokovic opened a vegan restaurant called Eqvita in [Monte Carlo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo "Monte Carlo").<sup id="cite_ref-647" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-647">[645]</a></sup> The restaurant reportedly closed in March 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-648" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-648">[646]</a></sup>

Djokovic has 80% stake in biotech firm QuantBioRes which claims to be developing a drug to treat patients who have contracted [COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19 "COVID-19").<sup id="cite_ref-649" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-649">[647]</a></sup> Their research is based on electromagnetic frequency; one biomedical scientist likened it to [homeopathy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homeopathy "Homeopathy") and argued that it "does not reflect a contemporary understanding of how biochemistry works", while [Peter Collignon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Collignon "Peter Collignon") commented that their website "describes a way of finding a new molecule without providing any evidence of success".<sup id="cite_ref-650" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-650">[648]</a></sup>

### Professional Tennis Players Association

In August 2020, Djokovic resigned from the Players Council of the [Association of Tennis Professionals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_of_Tennis_Professionals "Association of Tennis Professionals") and formed the [Professional Tennis Players Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Professional_Tennis_Players_Association "Professional Tennis Players Association") (PTPA) with [Vasek Pospisil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vasek_Pospisil "Vasek Pospisil"). The pair will serve as co-presidents of the new organisation to promote the interests of male and female tennis players above a ranking of 500 in singles and 200 in doubles.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTAug20_651-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-NYTAug20-651">[649]</a></sup>

### In popular culture

Throughout the latter part of the 2007 season, including before Wimbledon and during [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2007 US Open – Men's singles"), his comedic impressions of fellow contemporary tennis players received much media play.<sup id="cite_ref-652" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-652">[650]</a></sup> It began when a [BBC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC "BBC") camera crew recorded some footage of the twenty-year-old impersonating [Maria Sharapova](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maria_Sharapova "Maria Sharapova"), [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal"), [Goran Ivanišević](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goran_Ivani%C5%A1evi%C4%87 "Goran Ivanišević"), and [Lleyton Hewitt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lleyton_Hewitt "Lleyton Hewitt") on a practice court at London's [Queen's Club Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Stella_Artois_Championships_%E2%80%93_Singles "2007 Stella Artois Championships – Singles") just before Wimbledon.<sup id="cite_ref-Bowers2017-Ch7_653-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Bowers2017-Ch7-653">[651]</a></sup> The material — consisting of Djokovic imitating the said players by exaggerating their trademark physical gestures or nervous tics for the entertainment of his coaching team [Marián Vajda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mari%C3%A1n_Vajda "Marián Vajda") and [Mark Woodforde](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Woodforde "Mark Woodforde") — aired during BBC's coverage of the tournament and subsequently became popular online.<sup id="cite_ref-654" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-654">[652]</a></sup> Two months later at the US Open, a phone video shot by Argentine players of Djokovic doing locker room impressions of players such as [Andy Roddick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Roddick "Andy Roddick"), [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer"), [Filippo Volandri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filippo_Volandri "Filippo Volandri") and Nadal made its way online, becoming viral.<sup id="cite_ref-Bowers2017-Ch7_653-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Bowers2017-Ch7-653">[651]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-655" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-655">[653]</a></sup> A few days later, after beating [Carlos Moyá](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Moy%C3%A1 "Carlos Moyá") in the quarterfinals, [USA Network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USA_Network "USA Network")'s on-court interviewer [Michael Barkann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Barkann "Michael Barkann") asked Djokovic to perform some impressions and the player obliged by doing Sharapova and Nadal to the delight of the crowd.<sup id="cite_ref-Bowers2017-Ch7_653-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Bowers2017-Ch7-653">[651]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-656" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-656">[654]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-657" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-657">[655]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-658" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-658">[656]</a></sup>

In addition to Djokovic, the national surge in the popularity of tennis was also inspired by three other up-and-coming young players: twenty-year-old [Ana Ivanovic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ana_Ivanovic "Ana Ivanovic"), twenty-two-year-old [Jelena Janković](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jelena_Jankovi%C4%87 "Jelena Janković"), and twenty-three-year-old [Janko Tipsarević](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janko_Tipsarevi%C4%87 "Janko Tipsarević") as evidenced in early December 2007 when a sports-entertainment show named NAJJ Srbije (The Best of Serbia), put together in honour of the four players' respective successes in the 2007 season, drew a capacity crowd to Belgrade's Kombank Arena.<sup id="cite_ref-659" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-659">[657]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-660" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-660">[658]</a></sup> In May 2008, he was a special guest during the first semifinal of the [Eurovision Song Contest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2008 "Eurovision Song Contest 2008"), held in Belgrade that year. He threw a big tennis ball into the crowd, announcing the start of the voting and together with one of the show's co-presenters, [Željko Joksimović](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C5%BDeljko_Joksimovi%C4%87 "Željko Joksimović"), Djokovic sang [Đorđe Marjanović](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%90or%C4%91e_Marjanovi%C4%87 "Đorđe Marjanović")'s song "Beograde".<sup id="cite_ref-661" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-661">[659]</a></sup>

Throughout late April and early May 2009, during ATP Master Series tournaments in [Rome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Italian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2009 Italian Open – Men's singles") and [Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Mutua_Madrile%C3%B1a_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2009 Mutua Madrileña Madrid Open – Men's singles"), respectively, the Serb was a guest on the _[Fiorello Show](https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiorello_Show "it:Fiorello Show")_ on [Sky Uno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sky_Uno "Sky Uno") hosted by Italian comedian [Rosario Fiorello](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosario_Fiorello "Rosario Fiorello")<sup id="cite_ref-662" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-662">[660]</a></sup> followed by an appearance on [Pablo Motos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pablo_Motos "Pablo Motos")' show _[El Hormiguero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/El_Hormiguero "El Hormiguero")_.<sup id="cite_ref-663" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-663">[661]</a></sup>

Djokovic is also featured in the music video for the song "[Hello](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hello_(Martin_Solveig_song) "Hello (Martin Solveig song)")" by [Martin Solveig](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Solveig "Martin Solveig") and [Dragonette](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dragonette "Dragonette"). The video, filmed at [Stade Roland Garros](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stade_Roland_Garros "Stade Roland Garros"), shows Solveig facing off against [Bob Sinclar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Sinclar "Bob Sinclar"), another DJ, in a tennis match. When the referee calls a crucial ball "Out", Djokovic enters the arena and convinces the referee otherwise.<sup id="cite_ref-664" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-664">[662]</a></sup> In 2010, the Serbian [blues-rock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blues-rock "Blues-rock") band [Zona B](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zona_B "Zona B") recorded the song "The Joker", dedicating it to Djokovic.<sup id="cite_ref-665" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-665">[663]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-666" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-666">[664]</a></sup>

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Novak_Djokovic_in_Andricgrad.jpg/300px-Novak_Djokovic_in_Andricgrad.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Novak_Djokovic_in_Andricgrad.jpg)

Djokovic with [Emir Kusturica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emir_Kusturica "Emir Kusturica") in [Andrićgrad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andri%C4%87grad "Andrićgrad") in January 2014, where he received [Key to the City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Key_to_the_City "Key to the City")

On 25 June 2011, at the [Serbian National Defense Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbian_National_Defense_Council "Serbian National Defense Council")'s seventieth congress in [Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago "Chicago"), Djokovic was unanimously awarded the Order of Serbian National Defense in America I class – the highest decoration of the SND. The order was given to the twenty-four-year-old for his merits on the international sports scene and his contributions to the reputation of Serbs and Serbia around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-667" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-667">[665]</a></sup> The day after winning his first [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2011 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles") title and reaching the [No. 1 ranking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ATP_number_1_ranked_singles_tennis_players "List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players") for the first time in his career, Djokovic went home to Belgrade for a homecoming celebration in front of the [Serbian National Assembly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Assembly_(Serbia) "National Assembly (Serbia)"), an event attended by close to 100,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-668" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-668">[666]</a></sup>

On 28 November 2011, after returning from London where he finished early due to failing to progress out of his round-robin group, Djokovic visited his childhood tennis coach [Jelena Genčić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jelena_Gen%C4%8Di%C4%87 "Jelena Genčić") at her Belgrade home, bringing the Wimbledon trophy along.<sup id="cite_ref-669" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-669">[667]</a></sup> The meeting, reportedly their first in more than four years, was recorded by two television crews – a Serbian one shooting for [Aleksandar Gajšek](https://sr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandar_Gaj%C5%A1ek "sr:Aleksandar Gajšek")'s show _Agape_ on [Studio B](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RTV_Studio_B "RTV Studio B") television<sup id="cite_ref-670" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-670">[668]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-671" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-671">[669]</a></sup> and an American one from [CBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS "CBS") television network filming material for Djokovic's upcoming piece on _[60 Minutes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/60_Minutes "60 Minutes")_. The next day, 29 November 2011, on invitation from film producer [Avi Lerner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avi_Lerner "Avi Lerner"), Djokovic was part of the high-budget Hollywood movie production _[The Expendables 2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Expendables_2 "The Expendables 2")_ in a cameo playing himself<sup id="cite_ref-672" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-672">[670]</a></sup> that was shot in a warehouse in the Bulgarian capital of [Sofia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sofia "Sofia").<sup id="cite_ref-673" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-673">[671]</a></sup> However, his bit part was later cut out of the final version of the movie.<sup id="cite_ref-674" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-674">[672]</a></sup>

In March 2012, he was profiled on the CBS show _60 Minutes_ by their correspondent [Bob Simon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Simon "Bob Simon"). He was named amongst the [100 most influential people](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_100 "Time 100") of 2012 by _[TIME](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_(magazine) "Time (magazine)")_ magazine.<sup id="cite_ref-675" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-675">[673]</a></sup>

Djokovic has been a guest on [late-night talk shows](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late-night_talk_show "Late-night talk show"), such as _[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Tonight_Show_with_Jay_Leno "The Tonight Show with Jay Leno")_, _[Veče sa Ivanom Ivanovićem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ve%C4%8De_sa_Ivanom_Ivanovi%C4%87em "Veče sa Ivanom Ivanovićem")_, _[Conan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conan_(talk_show) "Conan (talk show)")_, _[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late_Night_with_Jimmy_Fallon "Late Night with Jimmy Fallon")_, _[Late Show with David Letterman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late_Show_with_David_Letterman "Late Show with David Letterman")_, _[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Late_Show_with_Stephen_Colbert "The Late Show with Stephen Colbert")_, _[The Jonathan Ross Show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Jonathan_Ross_Show "The Jonathan Ross Show")_ and _[The Ellen DeGeneres Show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Ellen_DeGeneres_Show "The Ellen DeGeneres Show")_.<sup id="cite_ref-676" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-676">[674]</a></sup>

In April 2021, a team of [Balkan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balkans "Balkans") biospeleologists named a recently discovered [freshwater snail](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freshwater_snail "Freshwater snail") species _Travunijana djokovici_ after Djokovic.<sup id="cite_ref-677" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-677">[675]</a></sup>

In 2022, a book titled _Facing Novak Djokovic_, a compilation of interviews with ATP players who described in detail what it's like to compete against Djokovic, was published.<sup id="cite_ref-678" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-678">[676]</a></sup>

In 2022, Nikola Vesović, a research associate at the [University of Belgrade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Belgrade "University of Belgrade"), announced that a new species of beetle in the genus _[Duvalius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duvalius "Duvalius")_ recently discovered near the town of [Ljubovija](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ljubovija "Ljubovija"), Serbia, had been named _Duvalius djokovici_ after Djokovic.<sup id="cite_ref-679" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-679">[677]</a></sup>

### Views on diet, medicine and science

Since 2010, he has been connected with the nutritionist Igor Četojević who additionally focuses on [Chinese medicine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine "Traditional Chinese medicine") and performs [acupuncture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acupuncture "Acupuncture").<sup id="cite_ref-čovek_582-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-%C4%8Dovek-582">[580]</a></sup> He allegedly discovered that Djokovic suffers from [gluten intolerance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gluten_intolerance "Gluten intolerance"), using [applied kinesiology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applied_kinesiology "Applied kinesiology"), and that he should not eat [gluten](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gluten "Gluten"), removing it from his diet.<sup id="cite_ref-Refrigerator_583-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Refrigerator-583">[581]</a></sup> He eventually settled on a [vegan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vegan "Vegan") diet, while later sometimes eating [fish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fish_as_food "Fish as food").<sup id="cite_ref-680" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-680">[678]</a></sup> He also claims this vegan, plant-based diet cured his persistent allergies and mild asthma.<sup id="cite_ref-681" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-681">[679]</a></sup> The gluten-free diet has been credited for improving his endurance on the court and playing a role in his subsequent success.<sup id="cite_ref-682" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-682">[680]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-683" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-683">[681]</a></sup>

Following his elbow surgery in 2018, he stated that he "cried for three days" after it, feeling guilty, because he was "not a fan of surgeries or medications" and wanted "to be as natural as possible". He further stated that his belief that human "bodies are self-healing mechanisms".<sup id="cite_ref-684" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-684">[682]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Clarey2020_685-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Clarey2020-685">[683]</a></sup>

In his 2013 autobiography, _Serve to Win_, he wrote of a "researcher" who directed "anger, fear, hostility" at a glass of water, which turned "slightly green" after a few days, while also directing "love, joy" at another glass of water, which remained "bright and crystal clear" in the same period.<sup id="cite_ref-Refrigerator_583-3" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Refrigerator-583">[581]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-686" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-686">[684]</a></sup> In 2020, Djokovic spoke of his belief that "some people" used "prayer" and "gratitude" to "turn the most toxic food, or maybe most polluted water into the most healing water." He also stated that "scientists \[have\] proven" that "molecules in the water react to our emotions" and speech.<sup id="cite_ref-687" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-687">[685]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-688" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-688">[686]</a></sup> Such claims are scientifically dubious,<sup id="cite_ref-689" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-689">[687]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-690" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-690">[688]</a></sup> and generally regarded as superstitious beliefs.<sup id="cite_ref-691" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-691">[689]</a></sup>

### Opposition to COVID-19 vaccine

See also: [2022 Australian Open § Djokovic's vaccination and visa controversy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Australian_Open#Djokovic's_vaccination_and_visa_controversy "2022 Australian Open")

During the ATP Tour's [shutdown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_sports "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on sports") due to the [COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic "COVID-19 pandemic"), in a Facebook live stream with other Serbian athletes hosted in April 2020, Djokovic indicated he [opposes vaccination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaccine_hesitancy "Vaccine hesitancy") and would not be forced to take a COVID vaccine just to be able to return to the Тour.<sup id="cite_ref-Clarey2020_685-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-Clarey2020-685">[683]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-692" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-692">[690]</a></sup> He later clarified his remarks by stating that he is not against all kinds of vaccines, but that he is against forced vaccination.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_693-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:3-693">[691]</a></sup> He added that he was extremely careful about what he puts into his body.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_693-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:3-693">[691]</a></sup>

Djokovic's views came under increased scrutiny in late 2021, in the run-up to the [2022 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Australian_Open "2022 Australian Open"), after comments made by [Australian government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_government "Australian government") officials indicated that tennis players would need to be vaccinated to enter the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-694" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-694">[692]</a></sup> Prior to the tournament, Djokovic had refused to state publicly whether he was vaccinated or not, but had made comments stating his concern over the possibility of a hotel quarantine in Australia.<sup id="cite_ref-695" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-695">[693]</a></sup> However, while being interviewed by the [Australian Border Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Border_Force "Australian Border Force") in January 2022, Djokovic confirmed to the officer interviewing him that he was unvaccinated.<sup id="cite_ref-696" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-696">[694]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-697" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-697">[695]</a></sup>

> "The principles of decision making on my body are more important than any title or anything else."

—Djokovic, on why he is willing to forgo playing major tournaments.

Several commentators feel that Djokovic's stance against the COVID-19 vaccine could damage his placement among the all-time great tennis players as he would not be able to participate in the major tournaments where vaccination is required for entry<sup id="cite_ref-698" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-698">[696]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-699" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-699">[697]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-700" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-700">[698]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-tennisconnected.com_701-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-tennisconnected.com-701">[699]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-702" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-702">[700]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-703" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-703">[701]</a></sup> while others have applauded his view of having a choice.<sup id="cite_ref-704" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-704">[702]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-705" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-705">[703]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-706" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-706">[704]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-707" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-707">[705]</a></sup> He was unable to play the [2022 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 Australian Open – Men's singles"), where he was the defending champion and the favourite to win.<sup id="cite_ref-22oddsAU_15-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-22oddsAU-15">[13]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-tennisconnected.com_701-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-tennisconnected.com-701">[699]</a></sup> Shortly thereafter, he lost the No. 1 ranking he had held for a record 373 weeks. Due to the federal government's vaccination policy for non-US citizens, Djokovic was unable to enter the United States to play the [2022 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 US Open – Men's singles"), another major tournament he was the favorite to win.<sup id="cite_ref-22oddsUS_16-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-22oddsUS-16">[14]</a></sup>

In an interview with the [BBC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_News "BBC News") on 15 February 2022, a few weeks after the tournament, Djokovic stated he does not associate with the wider [anti-vax movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-vaccine_activism "Anti-vaccine activism"). However, he believes in personal freedom of choice and supports an individual's right to choose whether or not they receive a vaccine. He re-affirmed sticking to his principles and refusal to receive a vaccine, saying that he would be willing to forego entry into tournaments which are held in countries mandating the vaccine even if it cost him his career records and placement among the all-time great players.<sup id="cite_ref-willing_14-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-willing-14">[12]</a></sup>

### Faith and religious beliefs

Djokovic is a member of the [Serbian Orthodox Church](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbian_Orthodox_Church "Serbian Orthodox Church"). On 28 April 2011, [Patriarch Irinej of Serbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patriarch_Irinej_of_Serbia "Patriarch Irinej of Serbia") awarded Djokovic the [Order of St. Sava](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_of_St._Sava "Order of St. Sava") I class, the highest decoration of the Serbian Orthodox Church, for his contributions to [monasteries of the Serbian Orthodox Church](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medieval_Monuments_in_Kosovo "Medieval Monuments in Kosovo") in [Kosovo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kosovo "Kosovo") and charitable work in Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-spc.rs_708-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-spc.rs-708">[706]</a></sup> He has said that he admired and held in high regard [Bishop Amfilohije](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amfilohije,_Metropolitan_of_Montenegro "Amfilohije, Metropolitan of Montenegro"), who played a key part in helping him through a tough time during the [Yugoslav Wars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yugoslav_Wars "Yugoslav Wars").<sup id="cite_ref-709" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-709">[707]</a></sup>

Djokovic has been reported to [meditate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist_meditation "Buddhist meditation") for up to an hour a day at the Buddhist [Buddhapadipa Temple](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wat_Buddhapadipa "Wat Buddhapadipa") in [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wimbledon,_London "Wimbledon, London") as he appreciates the natural setting and serenity, and is close to monks in the complex.<sup id="cite_ref-710" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-710">[708]</a></sup> He has spoken of the positive power of meditation.<sup id="cite_ref-711" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-711">[709]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-712" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-712">[710]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-713" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-713">[711]</a></sup> He is a frequent visitor of the [Bosnian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Bosnia and Herzegovina") town of [Visoko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visoko "Visoko") and [its park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bosnian_pyramid_claims#Tourism "Bosnian pyramid claims") that is host to several meditation platforms.<sup id="cite_ref-714" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-714">[712]</a></sup>

### Support of sport and sportspeople

Djokovic is a fan of Serbian football club [Red Star](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Star_Belgrade "Red Star Belgrade"),<sup id="cite_ref-715" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-715">[713]</a></sup> Italian club [Milan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A.C._Milan "A.C. Milan"),<sup id="cite_ref-716" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-716">[714]</a></sup> and Portuguese club [Benfica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S.L._Benfica "S.L. Benfica"),<sup id="cite_ref-717" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-717">[715]</a></sup> as well as Serbian basketball club [Red Star](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KK_Crvena_zvezda "KK Crvena zvezda").<sup id="cite_ref-718" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-718">[716]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-719" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-719">[717]</a></sup> He has also shown public support for [Croatia at the 2018 FIFA World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Croatia_at_the_2018_FIFA_World_Cup "Croatia at the 2018 FIFA World Cup") and when faced with criticism from some within his native country of Serbia, Djokovic replied that "sports have their 'universal language,' they erase boundaries between people, \[and\] overcome differences in religion, race and nationality."<sup id="cite_ref-:2_720-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:2-720">[718]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-721" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-721">[719]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-722" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-722">[720]</a></sup> Djokovic has expressed admiration for Croatian football player [Luka Modrić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luka_Modri%C4%87 "Luka Modrić"), who plays for [Real Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_Madrid_CF "Real Madrid CF").<sup id="cite_ref-:5_723-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:5-723">[721]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:6_724-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:6-724">[722]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:7_725-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-:7-725">[723]</a></sup> He is a friend of former Serbian tennis player [Ana Ivanovic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ana_Ivanovic "Ana Ivanovic"), whom he has known since the two were children growing up in Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-726" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-726">[724]</a></sup>

Djokovic is a member of the "Champions for Peace" club, a group of elite athletes committed to serving peace in the world through sport. It was created by Peace and Sport, a Monaco-based international organization.<sup id="cite_ref-727" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-727">[725]</a></sup>

### Political statements

Following Djokovic's victory over [Aleksandar Kovacevic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandar_Kovacevic_(tennis) "Aleksandar Kovacevic (tennis)") in the first round of the [2023 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_French_Open "2023 French Open"), Djokovic wrote "Kosovo is the heart of Serbia. Stop the violence" on the lens of a camera, in response to the recent [clashes in Kosovo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022%E2%80%932023_North_Kosovo_crisis#May "2022–2023 North Kosovo crisis"). The political statement was criticized as inappropriate by France's minister of sports [Amélie Oudéa-Castéra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Am%C3%A9lie_Oud%C3%A9a-Cast%C3%A9ra "Amélie Oudéa-Castéra").<sup id="cite_ref-728" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_note-728">[726]</a></sup>

1. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_ref-AU22_729-0 "Jump up")** Djokovic was scheduled to play the [2022 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 Australian Open – Men's singles"), but his [visa was cancelled](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#Australian_Open_controversy) for being unvaccinated against [COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19 "COVID-19").
2. ^ [Jump up to: <sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup>](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_ref-FO11_US16_730-0) [<sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup>](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_ref-FO11_US16_730-1) Djokovic had a [walkover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walkover_(tennis) "Walkover (tennis)") at the [2011 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles#Finals "2011 French Open – Men's singles") and another one at the [2016 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles#Section_1 "2016 US Open – Men's singles"); hence, these are not counted as wins.
3. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_ref-WM22_731-0 "Jump up")** The event of [2020 Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Wimbledon_Championships "2020 Wimbledon Championships") was not held due to the [COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic "COVID-19 pandemic").
4. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_ref-US20_732-0 "Jump up")** Djokovic was [disqualified](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_tennis_terms#Default "Glossary of tennis terms") from the [2020 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles#Section_1 "2020 US Open – Men's singles") after accidentally hitting a line official with a ball that was not in play.
5. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic#cite_ref-US22_733-0 "Jump up")** Djokovic withdrew from the [2022 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "2022 US Open – Men's singles") due to the federal government's [COVID-19 vaccination policy for non-US citizens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visa_policy_of_the_United_States#Restricted_entry_or_visa_issuance "Visa policy of the United States").
